It is inscribed with a diamond point
on the tablet of their heart
        and on the horns of their altars.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When their sons remember,
    they remember their altars and their Asherah poles
        beside green trees on the high hills.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
My mountain in the field, your wealth and your treasures
    I’ll give as spoil;
along with your high places as the price of your sin
    throughout your territory.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You will let go of your inheritance
    which I gave you,
and I’ll make you serve your enemies
    in a land that you don’t know.
For with my anger you have started a fire
    that will burn forever.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This is what the Lord says:
“Cursed is the person who trusts in mankind,
    who makes flesh his strength,
        and whose heart turns away from the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He will be like a bush in the desert,
    and he won’t see when good comes.
He will dwell in parched places in the wilderness,
    a land of salt, without inhabitants.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Blessed is the person who trusts in the Lord,
    making the Lord his trust.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He will be like a tree planted by the water
    that sends out its roots by a stream.
He won’t fear when the heat comes,
    and his leaves will be green.
In a year of drought he won’t be concerned,
    nor will he stop producing fruit.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“The heart is more deceitful than anything.
    It is incurable—
        who can know it?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I am the Lord who searches the heart,
    who tests the inner depths
to give to each person
    according to what he deserves,
        according to the fruit of his deeds.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
As a partridge gathers together eggs
    that it didn’t lay,
so is a person who amasses wealth unjustly.
    In the middle of his life it will leave him,
        and in the end he will prove to be a fool.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A glorious throne exalted from the beginning
    is the place of our sanctuary.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Lord, you are the hope of Israel;
    all who forsake you will be put to shame.
Those who turn aside from you will be
    written in the dust,
because they have forsaken the Lord,
    the spring of living water.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
Look, they’re saying to me,
    “Where is the message from the Lord?
        Let it come about!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I haven’t run away from being your shepherd,
    and I haven’t longed for the day of sickness.
You know what comes out from my lips,
    it’s open before you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Don’t be a terror to me.
    You are my refuge in a day of trouble.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Let those who pursue me be put to shame,
    but don’t put me to shame.
Let them be terrified,
    but don’t let me be terrified.
Bring the day of judgment on them,
    and destroy them with double destruction!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord told me, “Go, stand in the gate of the people, where the kings of Judah come in and go out, and in the other gates of Jerusalem as well.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Say to them, ‘Kings of Judah, all Judah, and all the residents of Jerusalem entering these gates, hear this message from the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is what the Lord says: “Be careful! On the Sabbath day, don’t carry any load or bring anything through the gates of Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Don’t bring any load out of your houses on the Sabbath day, nor are you to do any work. You are to consecrate the Sabbath day, just as I commanded your ancestors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But they didn’t listen, nor did they pay attention. They were determined not to listen and not to accept instruction.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If you listen to me carefully,” declares the Lord, “and don’t bring a load through the gates of this city on the Sabbath day, and you consecrate the Sabbath day and don’t do any work on it,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: then kings and princes, sitting on the throne of David will come through the gates of this city. They, their princes, the men of Judah, and the residents of Jerusalem will come riding in chariots and on horses, and this city will be inhabited forever.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They’ll come from the cities of Judah, from the places around Jerusalem, from the territory of Benjamin, from the Shephelah, from the hill country, and from the Negev, bringing burnt offerings, sacrifices, grain offerings, and incense, and bringing thanksgiving offerings to the Lord’s Temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But if you don’t listen to me, to consecrate the Sabbath day and not carry any load as you enter the gates of Jerusalem on the Sabbath day, then I’ll start a fire in its gates. It will consume the palaces of Jerusalem and won’t be extinguished.”’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The message that came to Jeremiah from the Lord:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Arise and go down to the potter’s house, and there I’ll allow you to hear my words.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So I went down to the potter’s house, and there he was doing work at the potter’s wheel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the vessel he was working on with the clay was ruined in the potter’s hand. So he remade it into another vessel that seemed appropriate to him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then this message from the Lord came to me:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Israel, can’t I deal with you like this potter?” declares the Lord. “Look, Israel, like clay in the potter’s hand, so are you in my hand.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At one moment I may speak about a nation or a kingdom to uproot it, pull it down, or destroy it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But if that nation about which I spoke turns from its evil way, I’ll change my mind about the disaster that I had planned for it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At another moment I may speak about a nation or kingdom to build it or plant it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But if that nation does evil in my eyes by not obeying me, I’ll change my mind about the good that I said I would bring on it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Now say to the people of Judah and to the residents of Jerusalem, ‘This is what the Lord says: “Look, I’m designing a disaster just for you, and I’m making plans against you. Each one of you must repent from his evil way. Make your ways and deeds right.”’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But they’ll say, ‘It’s useless! We will follow our plans and each of us will pursue his own evil desires.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Therefore, this is what the Lord says:
‘Ask the nations.
    Who has ever heard of anything like this?
You have done a most horrible thing,
    virgin Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Does the snow of Lebanon
    ever vanish from its rocky slopes?
Or does the cold water from a foreign land
    ever cease to flow?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Yet my people have forgotten me,
    and they burn incense to worthless idols
that make them stumble in their journey
    on the ancient paths.
They walk on trails,
    on a way that is not built up.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They make their land into a desolate place,
    an object of lasting scorn.
All who pass by will be appalled
    and will shake their heads.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
‘Like the east wind, I’ll scatter them
    before the enemy.
I’ll show them my back and not my face,
    on the day of their downfall.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then they said, “Come, let’s make up a plot against Jeremiah. After all, the priest’s instruction, the wise man’s counsel, and the prophet’s message won’t be destroyed. So let’s verbally attack him. Pay no attention to anything he says!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Lord, pay attention to me.
    Listen to the voice of my accusers!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Should good be repaid with evil?
    Yet they have dug a pit to take my life.
Remember! I stood before you
    and spoke good on their behalf
        in order to turn your wrath away from them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Therefore, make their children undergo famine,
    and deliver them over to death in time of war.
May their women be childless widows!
    May their men be slaughtered!
May their young men be slain
    by the sword in battle!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Let a cry be heard from their houses because you
    have brought a raiding party against them suddenly.
For they have dug a pit to capture me
    and have set traps for my feet.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But you, Lord, know all their plots to kill me.
    Don’t forgive their iniquity,
    and don’t erase their sin from your sight.
Let them stumble before you.
    When it’s time for you to be angry, act against them!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is what the Lord says: “Go and buy a potter’s clay jug. Take along some of the elders of the people and some of the elders of the priests.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Go out to the Valley of Hinnom at the entrance to the Potsherd Gate, and there proclaim the words that I’m telling you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“You are to say, ‘Hear this message from the Lord, you kings of Judah and residents of Jerusalem!
“‘This is what the Lord of the Heavenly Armies, the God of Israel, says: “I’m about to bring a disaster on this place that will make the ears of all who hear about it tingle.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For they have forsaken me and have treated this place as foreign. In it they have burned incense to other gods that neither they, their ancestors, nor the kings of Judah knew. They have also filled this place with the blood of innocent people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They built the high places for Baal to burn their children in the fire as a burnt offering to Baal—something I didn’t command, didn’t say, nor did it ever enter my mind!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “‘“Therefore, days are coming,” declares the Lord, “when this place will no longer be called Topheth, or the Valley of Hinnom, but rather the Valley of Slaughter.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I’ll shatter the counsel of Judah and Jerusalem in this place, and I’ll make them fall by the sword before their enemies and at the hands of those seeking their lives. I’ll give their dead bodies as food to the birds of the sky and to the animals of the land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I’ll make this city into a desolate place and an object of scorn. All who pass by it will be astonished and will scoff because of all its wounds.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I’ll cause them to eat the flesh of their sons and daughters, and people will eat the flesh of their neighbors in the siege and in the distress to which their enemies and those seeking their lives will subject them.”’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Then you are to break the jug in front of the men who have come with you,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and say to them, ‘This is what the Lord of the Heavenly Armies says: “In this same way I’ll break this people and this city, just as someone breaks a potter’s vessel which he then cannot put back together again. They’ll bury corpses in Topheth until there is no more room to bury anyone.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is what I’ll do to this place and its residents,” declares the Lord, “making this city like Topheth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The houses of Jerusalem and the houses of the kings of Judah will be polluted like Topheth, as will be all the houses on whose roofs people burned incense to all the host of heaven and poured out liquid offerings to other gods.”’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Jeremiah went from Topheth where the Lord had sent him to prophesy. He stood in the courtyard of the Lord’s Temple, saying to all the people,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “This is what the Lord of the Heavenly Armies, the God of Israel, says: ‘I’m about to bring on this city and all its towns all the disaster that I declared against it because they were determined not to obey my message.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the priest Pashhur, Immer’s son, who was the officer in charge of the Lord’s Temple heard Jeremiah prophesying these words,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pashhur struck Jeremiah the prophet and put him in the stocks that were at the upper Benjamin Gate of the Temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The next day, Pashhur released Jeremiah from the stocks, and Jeremiah told him, “The Lord has not named you Pashhur, but rather Magor-missabib.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For this is what the Lord says: ‘Look, I’m going to make you a terror to yourself and to all your loved ones. They’ll fall by the sword of their enemies, and your eyes will see it. I’ll give all Judah into the hand of the king of Babylon. He will take them into exile to Babylon, and he will execute them with swords.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I’ll turn over all the wealth of this city, all its possessions, all its valuables, and all the treasures of the kings of Judah right into the hands of their enemies, and they’ll plunder them, capture them, and take them to Babylon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You, Pashhur, and all those living in your house will go into captivity. You will go to Babylon and there you will die. There you and all your loved ones to whom you have falsely prophesied will be buried.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You deceived me, Lord,
    and I’ve been deceived.
You overpowered me,
    and you prevailed.
I’ve become a laughing stock all day long,
    and everyone mocks me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Indeed, as often as I speak, I cry out,
    and shout, “Violence and destruction!”
For this message from the Lord has caused me
    constant reproach and derision.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When I say, “I won’t remember the Lord,
    nor will I speak in his name anymore,
then there is this burning fire in my heart.
    It is bound up in my bones,
I grow weary of trying to hold it in,
    and I cannot do it!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Indeed, I hear many people whispering,
    “Terror on every side.
Denounce him, let’s denounce him!”
    All my close friends watch my steps and say,
“Perhaps he will be deceived,
    and we can prevail against him
        and take vengeance on him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But the Lord is with me like a fearsome warrior.
    Therefore, those who pursue me will stumble
        and won’t prevail.
They’ll be put to great shame,
    when they don’t succeed.
        Their everlasting disgrace won’t be forgotten.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Lord of the Heavenly Armies,
    who tests the righteous,
    who sees the inner motives and the heart,
let me see you take vengeance on them,
    for I’ve committed my case to you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Sing to the Lord,
    give praise to the Lord!
For he saves the life of the poor
    from the hand of the wicked.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Let the day on which I was born be cursed.
    Don’t let the day on which my mother gave birth to me be blessed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Cursed is the person who brought
    the good news to my father,
“A baby boy has been born to you,”
    making him very happy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
May that man be like the cities that
    the Lord overthrew without compassion.
Let him hear a cry in the morning,
    and a battle cry at noon,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
because he didn’t kill me in the womb,
    so that my mother would have been my grave
        and her womb forever pregnant.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Why did I ever come out of the womb
    to see trouble and sorrow,
        and to finish my life living in shame?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The message that came to Jeremiah from the Lord when King Zedekiah sent to him Malchijah’s son Pashhur and Maaseiah’s son Zephaniah the priest:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Please inquire of the Lord on our behalf, because King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon is fighting against us. Perhaps the Lord will do some of his miraculous acts for us, and Nebuchadnezzar will depart from us.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jeremiah told them, “This is what you are to say to Zedekiah,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘This is what the Lord God of Israel says: “I’m about to turn against you the weapons of war that are in your hands and with which you are fighting the king of Babylon and the Chaldeans who are besieging you outside the walls. I’ll gather them into the center of this city.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Because of my anger, wrath, and great fury, I’ll fight against you myself with an outstretched hand and a strong arm.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I’ll strike down the residents of this city, both people and animals, and they’ll die from a terrible plague.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Afterwards,” declares the Lord, “I’ll give King Zedekiah of Judah, his officials, and the people—those who are left in this city from the plague, the sword, and the famine—into the control of Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon, right into the hand of their enemies and the hand of those who want to kill them. He’ll execute them with swords and won’t pity them. He won’t spare them, nor will he have compassion on them.”’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “You are to say to this people, ‘This is what the Lord says: “I’m about to set before you the way of life and the way of death.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Whoever stays in this city will die by the sword, by famine, and by the plague. But whoever goes out and surrenders to the Chaldeans who are besieging you will live. He will save his life as a spoil of war.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Indeed, I’m firmly decided—I’m sending calamity to this city, not good,” declares the Lord. “It will be given into the hand of the king of Babylon, and he will set it on fire.”’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “To the house of the king of Judah say, ‘Hear this message from the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This is what the Lord says, house of David: 
“Judge appropriately every morning,
    and deliver those who have been robbed
        from the oppressor,
so my anger does not break out like fire
    and burn with no one to put it out
        because of your evil deeds.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Look, I’m against you,
    city dwelling in the valley,
rock of the plain,”
    declares the Lord,
“those of you who say, ‘Who can come down against us
    and who can enter our habitations?’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But I’ll punish you according to
    what you have done,”
        declares the Lord.
“I’ll start a fire in her forest,
    and it will consume everything around her.”’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is what the Lord says: “Go down to the house of the king of Judah and tell him this:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Listen to this message from the Lord, king of Judah, you who sit on the throne of David—you, your officials, and your people who enter these gates.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is what the Lord says: “Uphold justice and righteousness. Deliver from their oppressor those who have been robbed. Don’t mistreat or do violence to the alien, the orphan, or the widow, or shed the blood of innocent people in this place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Rather, carefully obey this message, and then kings sitting for David on his throne and riding in chariots and on horses will enter the gates of this house. The king will enter along with his officials and his people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But if you don’t listen to these words, I swear,” declares the Lord, “that this house will become a ruin.”’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
For this is what the Lord says about the house of the king of Judah,
“You are like Gilead to me,
    like the summit of Lebanon.
Yet I’ll surely make you a desert,
    towns where no one lives.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I’ll appoint people to destroy you—
    men with their weapons.
They’ll cut down some of your choice cedars
    and incinerate them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Many nations will pass by this city and say to one another, ‘Why did the Lord do this to this great city?’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then people will respond, ‘It is because they have forsaken the covenant of the Lord their God and have bowed down to other gods and served them.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Don’t cry for the dead
    or grieve for them.
Weep bitterly for the one going away,
    because he won’t return again
        nor see the land of his birth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “For this is what the Lord says about Josiah’s son Shallum, king of Judah, who reigned in place of his father Josiah: ‘He went out from this place and won’t return to it again.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He will die in the place where they exiled him, and he won’t ever see this land again.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“How terrible for him who builds his house
    without righteousness,
and its upper rooms without justice,
    who makes his neighbor work for nothing,
    and does not pay him his wage.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
How terrible for him who says, ‘I’ll build a large
    house for myself with spacious upper rooms,
who cuts out windows for it,
    paneling it with cedar and painting it red.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Are you a king because you try to outdo
    everyone with cedar?
Your father ate and drank and upheld
    justice and righteousness, did he not?
        And then it went well for him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He judged the case of the poor and needy.
    And then it went well for him.
        Isn’t this what it means to know me?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But your eyes and heart are on nothing but
    your dishonest gain,
shedding the blood of innocent people,
    and practicing oppression and extortion.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Therefore, this is what the Lord says about Josiah’s son Jehoiakim, king of Judah,
“They won’t lament for him with these words:
    ‘How terrible, my brother,
        How terrible, my sister!’
They won’t lament for him with these words:
    ‘How terrible, lord,
        How terrible, your majesty!’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He will receive a donkey’s burial,
    dragged out and thrown outside the gates of Jerusalem.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Go up to Lebanon and cry out,
    to Bashan and lift up your voice.
Cry out from Abarim, for all your lovers
    have been crushed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I spoke to you when you were secure,
    but you said, “I won’t listen!”
This has been your way since your youth,
    for you haven’t obeyed me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The wind will shepherd all your shepherds,
    and your lovers will go into exile.
Indeed, you will then be ashamed and humiliated
    because of all your wickedness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You who live in Lebanon,
    who build your nest in the cedars,
how you will groan when pains come upon you,
    pain like that of a woman giving birth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “As certainly as I’m alive and living,” declares the Lord, “even if Jehoiakim’s son King Jehoiachin of Judah were a signet ring on my right hand, I would pull you off
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and give you to those who are trying to kill you, whom you fear—that is, to King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon and the Chaldeans.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I’ll hurl you and the mother who gave birth to you into another land where you were not born, and there you will die.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As for the land to which you want to return, you won’t return there!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Is this man Jehoiachin a despised and shattered jar,
    a vessel no one wants?
Why were he and his descendants hurled away,
    thrown into a land that they didn’t know?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Land, land, land,
    listen to this message from the Lord!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This is what the Lord says:
‘Write this man off as childless,
    a man who does not prosper in his lifetime.
None of his descendants will succeed
    in sitting on the throne of David,
        or ever ruling in Judah again.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “How terrible for the shepherds who are destroying and scattering the sheep of my pasture!” declares the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Therefore, this is what the Lord God of Israel says about the shepherds who are shepherding my people, “You have scattered my flock and driven them away. You haven’t taken care of them, and now I’m about to take care of you because of your evil deeds,” declares the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “I’ll gather the remnant of my flock from all the countries where I’ve driven them, and bring them back to their pasture where they’ll be fruitful and increase in numbers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I’ll raise up shepherds over them, and they’ll shepherd them. My flock will no longer be afraid or terrified, and none will be missing,” declares the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“The time is coming,” declares the Lord,
    “when I’ll raise up a righteous branch for David.
He will be a king who rules wisely,
    and he will administer justice and righteousness in the land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
In his time Judah will be delivered
    and Israel will dwell in safety.
This is the name by which he will be known:
    ‘The Lord Our Righteousness.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Therefore, the time is coming,” declares the Lord, “when people will no longer say, ‘As surely as the Lord lives who brought up the Israelis from the land of Egypt,’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: but they’ll say, ‘As surely as the Lord lives who brought the descendants of the Israelis from the land of the north and from all the lands where I had driven them and brought them into the land.’ Then they’ll live in their own land.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Concerning the prophets:
My heart is broken within me,
    and all my bones shake.
I’m like a drunk man,
    like a person overcome with wine,
because of the Lord,
    and because of his holy words.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Indeed, the land is full of adulterers.
    Indeed, the land mourns because of the curse;
        the pastures of the wilderness have dried up.
The adulterers’ lifestyles are evil,
    and they use their strength for what is not right.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Indeed, both priest and prophet are ungodly.
    Even in my house I find evil,” declares the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Therefore their way will be slippery.
    They’ll be driven out into the darkness,
        where they’ll fall.
For I’ll bring disaster on them,
    the year of their judgment,”
        declares the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Among the prophets of Samaria I saw a disgusting thing,
    for they prophesied by Baal
        and led my people Israel astray.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Among the prophets of Jerusalem I saw a horrible thing,
    for they commit adultery and live a lie.
They strengthen the hands of those who do evil,
    so that no one repents of his evil.
All of them are like Sodom to me,
    and her residents like Gomorrah.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Therefore, this is what the Lord God of the Heavenly Armies says about the prophets,
“I’m about to make them eat wormwood
    and drink poisoned water,
because godlessness has spread from the
    prophets of Jerusalem throughout the land.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This is what the Lord of the Heavenly Armies says: 
“Don’t listen to the words of the prophets
    who are prophesying to you;
        they’re giving you false hopes.
They declare visions from their own minds—
    they don’t come from the Lord!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They keep on saying to those who despise me,
    ‘The Lord has said, “You will have peace.”’
To all who stubbornly follow their own desires they say,
    ‘Disaster won’t come upon you.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But who has stood in the Lord’s council
    to see and hear his message?
        Who has paid attention to his message and obeyed it?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Look, the storm of the Lord’s wrath has gone forth,
    a whirling tempest,
and it will swirl down
    around the head of the wicked.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The Lord’s anger won’t turn back
    until he has accomplished
        what he intended to do.
In the future
    you will clearly understand it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I didn’t send these prophets,
    but they ran anyway.
I didn’t speak to them,
    but they prophesied.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If they had stood in my council
    and had delivered my words to my people,
then they would have turned them back
    from their evil way,
        from their evil deeds.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Am I a God who is near,” declares the Lord,
    “rather than a God who is far away?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If a person hides himself in secret places,
    will I not see him?”
        declares the Lord.
“I fill the heavens and the earth, do I not?”
    declares the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “I’ve heard what the prophets who prophesy lies in my name have said: ‘I had a dream; I had a dream.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: How long will this go on? Is there anything in the hearts of the prophets who prophesy lies, and who prophesy from the deceit that is in their hearts?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: With their dreams that they relate to one another, they plan to make my people forget my name just as their ancestors forgot my name by embracing Baal.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Let the prophet who has a dream relate the dream, but let whoever receives my message speak my message truthfully. What does straw have in common with wheat?” declares the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “My message is like fire or like a hammer that shatters rock, is it not?” declares the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Therefore, look, I’m against the prophets,” declares the Lord, “who steal my words from each other.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Look, I’m against the prophets,” declares the Lord, “who use their tongues to issue a declaration.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Look, I’m against those who prophesy based on false dreams,” declares the Lord, “and relate them and lead my people astray with their lies and their recklessness. I didn’t send them; I didn’t command them, and they provide no benefit at all to these people,” declares the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Jeremiah, when these people, the prophet, or a priest ask you, ‘What is the oracle of the Lord?’ say to them, ‘You are the burden, and I’ll cast you out,’” declares the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “As for the prophet, the priest, or the people who say, ‘I have an oracle of the Lord,’ I’ll judge that person and his household.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is what you should say to one another and among yourselves, ‘What has the Lord answered?’ or ‘What has the Lord said?’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But you are to no longer mention the oracle of the Lord, because the oracle is only for the person to whom the Lord gives his message, and you have overturned the words of the living God, the Lord of the Heavenly Armies, our God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is what you should say to the prophet, ‘What has the Lord answered?’ or ‘What has the Lord said?’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Since you’re saying, ‘We have an oracle of the Lord,’ therefore this is what the Lord says: He will answer your message with this message, ‘Burden of the Lord,’ and I’ll send you away with these words: ‘Don’t say, “Oracle of the Lord.”’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Therefore I’ll surely forget you and cast you and the city I gave you and your ancestors out of my presence.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I’ll bring on you everlasting reproach and everlasting humiliation that won’t ever be forgotten.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylon, had taken Jehoiakim’s son Jeconiah, king of Judah, along with the officials of Judah, the craftsmen, and the smiths from Jerusalem into exile, and had brought them to Babylon, the Lord showed me two baskets of figs placed right in front of the Temple of the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: One basket contained very good figs like the first figs that ripen on the tree. The other basket contained very bad figs that were too bad to be eaten.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The Lord told me, “What do you see?”
I replied, “Figs. The good figs are very good, and the bad figs are very bad. They’re too bad to be eaten.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then this message from the Lord came to me:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “This is what the Lord God of Israel says: ‘Like these good figs, so I’ll regard as good the exiles of Judah whom I sent from this place to the land of the Chaldeans.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I’ll look at them with good intentions, and I’ll bring them back to this land. I’ll build them up. I won’t tear them down; I’ll plant them and not rip them up.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I’ll give them the ability to know me, for I am the Lord. They will be my people, and I will be their God when they return to me with all their heart.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “‘Like the bad figs that are too bad to be eaten—for this is what the Lord says—so I’ll give up on Zedekiah king of Judah, along with his officials, the remnant of Jerusalem that is left in this land, and those living in the land of Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I’ll make them into a horrifying sight to all the kingdoms of the earth; into a cause for contempt, into a byword, into a taunt, and into a curse in all the places to which I drive them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I’ll send the sword, famine, and plague against them until they’re completely destroyed from the land which I gave them and their ancestors.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This message from the Lord came to Jeremiah concerning all the people of Judah in the fourth year of Josiah’s son Jehoiakim, king of Judah. (This was also the first year of the reign of King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is what Jeremiah the prophet told all the people of Judah and all the residents of Jerusalem:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “From the thirteenth year of the reign of Ammon’s son Josiah, the king of Judah, until the present time, for 23 years this message from the Lord has come to me, and I’ve spoken to you again and again, but you haven’t listened.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Again and again, the Lord sent all his servants, the prophets, to you, but you wouldn’t listen or even turn your ears in my direction to hear.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They said, ‘Turn, each one of you, from your evil habits and evil deeds, and live in the land that the Lord gave to you and your ancestors forever and ever.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Don’t follow other gods to serve and worship them. Don’t provoke me with the idols you make with your hands, and I won’t bring disaster on you.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But you didn’t listen to me,” declares the Lord, “so as to provoke me with the idols you make with your hands to your own harm.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Therefore, this is what the Lord of the Heavenly Armies says: ‘Because you haven’t listened to my message,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I’m now sending for all the tribes from the north, declares the Lord, and for my servant Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon. I’ll bring them against this land, against its inhabitants, and against all these surrounding nations. I’ll utterly destroy them and make them an object of horror and scorn, and an everlasting desolation.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I’ll destroy the sounds of gladness and rejoicing from them, the sounds of the bridegroom and the bride, the sound of the hand mill and also the light of the lamp.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This entire land will be a desolation and a waste, and these nations will serve the king of Babylon for seventy years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Then when the seventy years have passed, I’ll judge the king of Babylon and that nation, declares the Lord, I’ll judge the land of the Chaldeans for their iniquity and I’ll make it a desolation forever.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I’ll bring on that land all the things I spoke against it, all that is written in this book, which Jeremiah prophesied about the nations.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Indeed many nations and great kings will make slaves even of them, and I’ll repay them according to their deeds, according to what they have done.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For this is what the Lord God of Israel says to me, “Take this cup of the wine of burning anger from my hand and make all the nations to whom I send you drink it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They’ll drink, stagger, and act like madmen because of the sword I’m sending among them.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So I took the cup from the Lord’s hand, and I made all the nations to whom the Lord sent me drink it:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jerusalem, the cities of Judah, its kings and officials to make them into a ruin, an object of horror and scorn, and a curse, as it is this day;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pharaoh, king of Egypt, his officials, his princes, and all his people;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: all the various people; all the kings of the land of Uz, all the kings of the land of the Philistines, Ashkelon, Gaza, Ekron, and what remains of Ashdod;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Edom, Moab, and the people of Ammon;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: all the kings of Tyre, all the kings of Sidon, and all the kings of the coast lands that are beyond the sea;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Dedan, Tema, Buz, and those who shave the corners of their beards;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: all the kings of Arabia and all the kings of the various people who live in the desert;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: all the kings of Zimri, all the kings of Elam, and all the kings of Media;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: all the kings of the north near and far, one after another, and all the kingdoms of the world on the face of the earth. The king of Sheshak will drink after all the others.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “You are to say to them, ‘This is what the Lord of the Heavenly Armies, the God of Israel, says: “Drink, get drunk, and vomit! Fall down and don’t get up because of the sword I’m sending among you.”’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And if they refuse to take the cup from your hand to drink it, say to them, ‘This is what the Lord of the Heavenly Armies says: “You will surely drink it!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Look, I’m beginning to bring disaster on the city that is called by my name, and do you actually think you will avoid punishment? You won’t avoid punishment because I’m summoning the sword against all those who live in the land,” declares the Lord of the Heavenly Armies.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“You are to prophesy all these things against them, and you are to say to them,
‘The Lord roars from his high place,
    from his holy dwelling he lifts his voice.
He roars loudly against his flock,
    and against all who live on the earth;
        he shouts like those treading grapes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A tumult reaches to the ends of the earth
    because the Lord is bringing an indictment against the nations.
He judges all flesh.
    He has given the wicked over to the sword,’
        declares the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
‘This is what the Lord of the Heavenly Armies says:
    “Look, disaster is going from nation to nation,
a great storm is being stirred up
    from the most distant parts of the earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Those slain by the Lord on that day will extend from one end of the earth to the other. They won’t be mourned for or gathered up or buried. They’ll be like dung on the surface of the ground.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Scream, you shepherds! Cry out!
    Roll in the dust, you leaders of the flock!
Indeed, the time for your slaughter
    and your dispersion has arrived,
        and you will break like a choice vessel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Flight will be impossible for the shepherds,
    as will be escape for the leaders of the flock.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A sound—it’s the cry of the shepherds
    and the scream of the leaders of the flock—
        because the Lord is destroying their pastures.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The peaceful meadows are silent
    because of the Lord’s fierce anger.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Like a lion, he has left his den.
    Indeed, their land has become a waste
because of the anger of the oppressor
    and because of the Lord’s fierce anger.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the beginning of the reign of Josiah’s son Jehoiakim, king of Judah, this message came from the Lord:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “This is what the Lord says: ‘Stand in the courtyard of the Lord’s Temple and tell those from all the cities of Judah who are coming to worship at the Lord’s Temple everything that I’ve commanded you to say to them. Don’t leave out a word!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Perhaps they’ll listen, and each of them will repent from his evil way. Then I’ll change my mind about the disaster I’m planning to bring on them because of their evil deeds.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Say to them, “This is what the Lord says: ‘If you don’t listen to me to follow my Law which I’ve set before you,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and listen to the words of my servants, the prophets, whom I’ve sent to you over and over—but you wouldn’t listen—
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: then I’ll make this house like Shiloh and make this city into a curse to all the nations of the earth.’”’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The priests, the prophets, and all the people listened as Jeremiah spoke these words at the Lord’s Temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As soon as Jeremiah finished saying everything that the Lord had commanded him to say to all the people, the priests, the prophets, and all the people seized him, telling him as they did: “You must certainly die!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Why have you prophesied in the name of the Lord that this house will be like Shiloh, and this city will be without an inhabitant?” Then all the people gathered around Jeremiah at the Lord’s Temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the Judean officials heard all these things, they came up from the king’s house to the Lord’s Temple and sat in the doorway of the New Gate of the Lord’s Temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The priests and prophets told the officials and all the people, “A death sentence for this man, because he prophesied against this city, as you heard with your own ears!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Jeremiah spoke to all the officials and to all the people: “The Lord has sent me to prophesy all the things you heard against this house and against this city.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now, change your habits and your deeds and obey the Lord your God, and the Lord will change his mind about the disaster that he told you about.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Look, I’m in your hands, so do with me what you think is good and right.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But know for certain that if you kill me, you will bring innocent blood on yourselves and on this city and its residents because the Lord really did send me to you to say all these things for you to hear.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The officials and all the people told the priests and the prophets, “No death sentence for this man because he has spoken to us in the name of the Lord our God.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Some of the elders of the land got up and told all the assembled people,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Micah of Moresheth prophesied during the reign of Hezekiah king of Judah to all the people of Judah, ‘This is what the Lord of the Heavenly Armies says:
“Zion will be a plowed field,
    and Jerusalem a ruin.
        The Temple Mount will be a wooded hill.”’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Did Hezekiah king of Judah or anyone in Judah kill him? Didn’t he fear the Lord and seek the Lord’s favor, and so the Lord changed his mind about the disaster that he had spoken to them about. We’re bringing great disaster on ourselves.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There was also a man named Uriah, Shemaiah’s son from Kiriath-jearim, who prophesied in the Lord’s name. He prophesied about this city and this land in words similar to those of Jeremiah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Jehoiakim, all his troops, and all the officials heard his words, and the king sought to kill him. Uriah heard about this and was afraid, so he fled and went to Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Jehoiakim sent men to Egypt. He sent Achbor’s son Elnathan, along with a contingent of men into Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They brought Uriah out of Egypt and brought him to King Jehoiakim, who killed him with a sword. Then they threw his body into a common grave.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Yet because Shaphan’s son Ahikam supported Jeremiah, he was not handed over to the people for them to kill.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At the beginning of the reign of Josiah’s son Jehoiakim, king of Judah, this message came to Jeremiah from the Lord:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: this is what the Lord says to me: “Make restraints and yokes for yourself and put them on your neck.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then send messengers to the king of Edom, the king of Moab, the king of the Ammonites, the king of Tyre, and the king of Sidon through the envoys who come to Jerusalem to king Zedekiah of Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Give them this order for their masters: ‘This is what the Lord of the Heavenly Armies, the God of Israel, says, and this is what you are to say to your masters,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “By my great power and outstretched arm I made the earth, mankind, and the animals that are on the face of the earth, and I give it to whomever I see fit.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now I’ve given all these lands to my servant, Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon, and I’ve even given him the wild animals to serve him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the nations will serve him, his son, and his grandson until his country’s time also comes, and then many nations and great kings will use him as a slave.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If a nation and kingdom does not serve him—King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon—and does not put its neck under the yoke of the king of Babylon, I’ll judge that nation with the sword, with famine, and with plague,” declares the Lord, “until I’ve completely destroyed it by his hand.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You aren’t to listen to your prophets, your diviners, your dreamers, your soothsayers, and your sorcerers who say to you, ‘Don’t serve the king of Babylon.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They’re prophesying a lie to you in order to remove you far away from your land. I’ll drive you out and you will perish.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But I’ll let the nation that brings its neck under the yoke of the king of Babylon and serves him remain in its own land,” declares the Lord, “and they’ll work it and remain in it.”’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I spoke to Zedekiah king of Judah using words like these: “Bring your neck under the yoke of the king of Babylon. Serve him and his people, and you will live!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Why should you and your people die by the sword, by famine, and by plague as the Lord has decreed about the nation that does not serve the king of Babylon?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Don’t listen to the words of the prophets who say to you, ‘You won’t serve the king of Babylon.’ Indeed, they’re prophesying a lie to you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For I didn’t send them,” declares the Lord, “and they’re falsely prophesying in my name, so I will drive both you and the prophets who prophesy to you out of the land.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then I spoke to the priests and all of the people: “This is what the Lord says: ‘Don’t listen to the words of the prophets who prophesy to you: “The vessels from the Temple are about to be returned from Babylon very soon now.” Indeed, they’re prophesying a lie to you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Don’t listen to them! Serve the king of Babylon and you’ll live. Why should this city become a ruin?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If they’re prophets, and if they have a message from the Lord, let them plead with the Lord of the Heavenly Armies so that the utensils that remain in the Lord’s Temple, in the house of the king of Judah, and in Jerusalem might not be taken to Babylon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For this is what the Lord of the Heavenly Armies says about the pillars, the bronze sea, the stands, and the rest of the vessels that remain in this city
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: that Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon didn’t take when he took Jehoiakim’s son Jeconiah, king of Judah, and all the nobles of Judah and Jerusalem from Jerusalem into exile to Babylon—
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For this is what the Lord of the Heavenly Armies, the God of Israel says about the vessels that remain in the Lord’s Temple, in the house of the king of Judah, and in Jerusalem,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “They’ll go into Babylon and there they’ll remain until the time I take note of them,” declares the Lord. “Then I’ll bring them up and return them to this place.”’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In that same year, in the beginning of the reign of Zedekiah, king of Judah, in the fourth year and the fifth month, Azzur’s son Hananiah, the prophet from Gibeon, told me at the Lord’s Temple in front of the priests and all the people,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “This is what the Lord of the Heavenly Armies, the God of Israel, says: ‘I’ve broken the yoke of the king of Babylon,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and within two years I’ll bring back to this place all the vessels of the Lord’s Temple that Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon took from this place and carried to Babylon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I’ll bring back Jehoiakim’s son Jeconiah, king of Judah, and all the exiles of Judah who went to Babylon to this place,’ declares the Lord, ‘for I’ll break the yoke of the king of Babylon.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The prophet Jeremiah spoke to the prophet Hananiah in front of the priests and all the people who were standing in the Lord’s Temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The prophet Jeremiah said, “May the Lord truly do this thing! May the Lord fulfill the words that you prophesied to bring back the vessels of the Lord’s Temple and all the exiles from Babylon to this place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But please listen to what I’m saying in your hearing and in the hearing of all the people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The prophets who came before us from ancient times prophesied war, famine, and plague against many lands and great kingdoms.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When a prophet prophesies peace, and what the prophet speaks comes about, he will be known as the prophet whom the Lord has truly sent.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the prophet Hananiah took the yoke from the neck of Jeremiah the prophet and broke it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hananiah, in front of all the people, said, “This is what the Lord says: ‘In the same way, within two years, I’ll break the yoke of Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon from the neck of all the nations.’” Then Jeremiah the prophet went on his way.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This message from the Lord came to Jeremiah after the prophet Hananiah had broken the yoke from the neck of Jeremiah the prophet:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Go and say to Hananiah, ‘This is what the Lord says: “You have broken wooden yokes, but you have made iron yokes in their place.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For this is what the Lord of the Heavenly Armies, the God of Israel, says: “I’ve put an iron yoke on the necks of all these nations to serve Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon. They’ll serve him, and I’ve even given the wild animals to him.”’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The prophet Jeremiah told the prophet Hananiah, “Listen, Hananiah! The Lord didn’t send you, and you are causing these people to trust in a lie.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Therefore, this is what the Lord says: ‘I’m about to remove you from the face of the earth. This year you will die because you have preached rebellion against the Lord.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the prophet Hananiah died in the seventh month of that year.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These are the words of the letter that the prophet Jeremiah sent from Jerusalem to the remaining elders among the exiles, to the priests, to the prophets, and to all the people whom Nebuchadnezzar had taken into exile from Jerusalem to Babylon,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: after King Jeconiah, the queen mother, the palace officials, the officials of Judah and Jerusalem, the craftsmen, and the smiths left Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The letter was sent by Shaphan’s son Elasah and by Hilkiah’s son Gemariah, whom King Zedekiah of Judah sent to Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon in Babylon, and it said,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “This is what the Lord of the Heavenly Armies, the God of Israel, says to all the exiles who were taken from Jerusalem into exile to Babylon,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Build houses and live in them. Plant gardens and eat their produce.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Take wives and father sons and daughters. Take wives for your sons and give your daughters in marriage, so they may have sons and daughters. Increase in numbers there, don’t decrease.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Seek the welfare of the city to which I’ve exiled you and pray to the Lord for it, for your welfare depends on its welfare.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For this is what the Lord of the Heavenly Armies, the God of Israel, says: ‘Don’t let the prophets and diviners who are among you deceive you, and don’t listen to them when they tell you their dreams.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Indeed, they’re prophesying lies to you in my name. I didn’t send them,’ declares the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “For this is what the Lord says: ‘When Babylon’s seventy years are completed, I’ll take note of you and will fulfill my good promises to you by bringing you back to this place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For I know the plans that I have for you,’ declares the Lord, ‘plans for well-being, and not for calamity, in order to give you a future and a hope.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When you call out to me and come and pray to me, I’ll hear you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You will seek me and find me when you search for me with all your heart.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I’ll be found by you,’ declares the Lord, ‘and I’ll restore your security and gather you from all the nations and all the places to which I’ve driven you,’ declares the Lord. ‘I’ll bring you back to the place from which I sent you into exile.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Indeed, you have said, ‘The Lord has raised up prophets for us in Babylon.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “But this is what the Lord says about the king who sits on David’s throne, and about the people who live in this city—your brothers who didn’t go with you into exile:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is what the Lord says: ‘I’m about to send the sword, famine, and plague on them, and I’ll make them like rotten figs that cannot be eaten because they’re so bad.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I’ll pursue them with the sword, with famine, and with plague, and I’ll make them a horrifying sight to all the kingdoms of the earth. I’ll make them a curse, an object of horror, and scorn, and a desolation in all the nations to which I’ve driven them,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: because they didn’t listen to my words,’ declares the Lord. ‘When I sent my servants, the prophets, to you again and again, you didn’t listen,’ declares the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Now, all you exiles whom I sent from Jerusalem to Babylon, listen to this message from the Lord!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is what the Lord of the Heavenly Armies, the God of Israel, says about Kolaiah’s son Ahab and Maaseiah’s son Zedekiah, who are prophesying lies to you in my name, ‘I’m about to give them into the domination of Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon, and he will kill them before your eyes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: What happens to them will be the basis for a curse for all the Judean exiles who are in Babylon. People will say, “May the Lord make you like Zedekiah and Ahab, whom the Lord roasted in the fire,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: because they did something stupid in Israel. They committed adultery with their neighbors’ wives, and in my name they spoke lies that I didn’t command them. I’m the one who knows, and I’m a witness,” declares the Lord.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “You are to say to Shemaiah of Nehelam:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘This is what the Lord of the Heavenly Armies, the God of Israel, says: “Because you sent letters in your own name to all the people who are in Jerusalem, to Maaseiah’s son Zephaniah the priest and to all the priests—
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord made you a priest instead of Jehoiada the priest to serve in the Lord’s Temple as an official against every crazy prophet, and to put him in stocks and restraints.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And now, why didn’t you rebuke Jeremiah from Anathoth who prophesies to you?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So he sent a message to us in Babylon: ‘The exile will be long, so build houses and live in them. Plant gardens and eat their produce.’”’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Zephaniah the priest read this letter to Jeremiah the prophet,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and this message from the Lord came to Jeremiah:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Send a message to all the exiles: ‘This is what the Lord says about Shemaiah from Nehelam, “Because Shemaiah has prophesied to you, even though I didn’t send him, and has made you trust a lie,”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: therefore, this is what the Lord says: “I’m about to judge Shemaiah from Nehelam along with his descendants. He won’t have anyone related to him living among these people. Nor will he see the good that I’ll do for my people,” declares the Lord, “because he advocated rebellion against the Lord.”’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This message came from the Lord to Jeremiah:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “This is what the Lord God of Israel says: ‘Write all the words that I’ve spoken to you in a book.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Indeed, the time will come,’ declares the Lord, ‘when I’ll restore the security of my people Israel and Judah,’ says the Lord. ‘I’ll bring them back to the land that I gave to their ancestors, and they’ll possess it.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These are the words that the Lord spoke about Israel and Judah:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Indeed, this is what the Lord says: 
‘We have heard a sound of terror
    and of fear, and there is no peace.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Ask about this and think about it—
    Can a man give birth to a child?
Why then do I see every strong man
    with his hands on his thighs
like a woman giving birth,
    and all their faces have turned pale?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Oh how terrible! That time will be worse
    than any like it.
It will be a time of trouble for Jacob,
    but he will be rescued from it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
On that day,’ declares the Lord
    of the Heavenly Armies,
‘I’ll break the yoke from your neck
    and will tear off your restraints.
        Foreigners will no longer make you serve them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Rather, they will serve the Lord their God
    and David their king,
        whom I will raise up for them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
‘My servant Jacob, don’t be afraid,’ declares the Lord,
    ‘and Israel, don’t be dismayed.
For I’ll deliver you from a distant place
    and your descendants from the land of their captivity.
Jacob will return. He will be undisturbed and secure,
    and no one will cause him to fear.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
For I’ll be with you to save you,’
    declares the Lord.
‘For I’ll put an end to all the nations
    where I scattered you;
        but I won’t make an end of you.
I’ll discipline you justly,
    but I certainly won’t leave you unpunished.’
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
All your lovers have forgotten you;
    they don’t seek you.
Indeed, I’ve struck you down
    with the blow of an enemy,
        with the punishment of a cruel foe
because your wickedness is great,
    and your sins are numerous.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Why do you cry out because of your injury?
    Your wound won’t heal.
Because your wickedness is severe,
    and your sins are numerous,
        I’ve done all these things to you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
In addition, all who devour you will be devoured,
    and all your oppressors—all of them—
        will go into captivity.
Those who plunder you will become plunder,
    and all who spoil you will become spoil.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Indeed, I’ll bring you healing,
    and I’ll heal you of your wounds,’
        declares the Lord,
‘because they have called you an outcast
    and have said, “It is Zion, no one cares for her!”’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“This is what the Lord says:
‘I’m going to restore the fortunes of the tents of Jacob
    and have compassion on his dwellings.
A city will be rebuilt on its ruins
    and a palace will sit on its rightful place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Thanksgiving and the sounds of laughter
    will come out of them.
I’ll cause them to increase in numbers and not decrease.
    I’ll honor them and not make them insignificant.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Their children will be as they were before,
    and their congregation will be established before me.
I’ll punish all who oppress them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Their leader will be one of their own,
    and their ruler will come from among them.
I’ll bring him near, and he will approach me,
    for who would otherwise dare to approach me?’
        declares the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
‘You will be my people,
    and I’ll be your God.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Look, the storm of the Lord!
    His wrath has gone forth, a twisting storm.
        It will swirl around the head of the wicked.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The fierce anger of the Lord won’t turn back
    until he has accomplished and established the plan of his heart.
In the days to come, you will understand this.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “At that time,” declares the Lord, “I’ll be the God of all the families of Israel, and they will be my people.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This is what the Lord says:
“The people who survived the sword,
    found favor in the desert
        while Israel was seeking rest.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The Lord appeared to Israel from far away and said,
    “I’ve loved you with an everlasting love,
        therefore I’ve drawn you with gracious love.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I’ll again build you, and you will be rebuilt,
    Virgin Israel!
You will again take up your tambourines
    and go out to dance with those who are filled with joy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You will again plant vineyards on the hills of Samaria
    where planters had planted and defiled the fruit.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
For there will be a day when the watchmen
    will call out on the hills of Ephraim,
    ‘Arise, let’s go up to Zion to the Lord our God.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
For this is what the Lord says:
“Cry out with joy for Jacob
    and shout for the chief among the nations.
Announce, give praise, and say,
    ‘Lord, save your people, the remnant of Israel.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Look, I’m bringing them from the northern region,
    and I’ll gather them from the farthest parts of the earth.
Among them will be the blind and the lame,
    together with the pregnant woman
        and the woman in labor.
A large group will return here.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They’ll come crying,
    and I’ll lead them as they pray for mercy.
I’ll make them walk by streams of water,
    along a straight path on which they won’t stumble.
For I am Israel’s father,
    and Ephraim is my firstborn.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Nations, listen to this message from the Lord,
    and declare it in the distant coastlands.
Say, “The one who scattered Israel will gather him
    and keep him as a shepherd keeps his flock.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
For the Lord will deliver Jacob
    and redeem him from the hand of one stronger than he.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They’ll come and cry out with joy
    on the heights of Zion.
They’ll be radiant over the Lord’s goodness,
    over the grain, the new wine, the fresh oil,
        and over the young of the flocks and herds.
Their lives will be like a well-watered garden.
    They’ll never again grow faint.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The virgins will rejoice with dancing,
    together with young men and old men.
For I’ll turn their mourning into joy,
    and I’ll comfort them and give them gladness
        instead of sorrow.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I’ll give the priests abundant provisions,
    and my people will be satisfied with my goodness,”
        declares the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This is what the Lord says: 
“A voice is heard in Ramah,
    lamentation and bitter crying.
Rachel is crying,
    and she refuses to be comforted for her children,
        because they are no longer alive.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This is what the Lord says: 
“Restrain your voice from crying,
    and your eyes from tears,
for there is a reward for your work,”
    declares the Lord.
        “They’ll return from the enemy’s land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
There is hope for your future,”
    declares the Lord.
“Your children will return to their own territory.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“I’ve certainly heard Ephraim
    shuddering with grief as they said,
‘You have disciplined me,
    and I’m disciplined like an untrained calf.
Restore me, and let me return,
    for you are the Lord my God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Indeed, after I turned away, then I repented.
    And after I came to understand,
        I slapped my forehead.
I was both ashamed and humiliated
    because I bear the disgrace of my youth.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Is Ephraim my dear son?
    Is he a darling child?
Indeed, as often as I’ve spoken about him,
    I surely still remember him.
Therefore I deeply yearn for him.
    I’ll surely have great compassion on him,”
        declares the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Set up markers for yourselves.
    Erect signposts for yourselves.
Pay attention to the highway,
    to the road you traveled.
Return, virgin Israel,
    return to these cities of yours.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
How long will you go this way and that,
    rebellious daughter?
Indeed, the Lord will create a new thing on the earth;
    a woman will protect a man.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is what the Lord of the Heavenly Armies, the God of Israel, says: “They’ll again speak this message in the land of Judah and its towns when I restore their fortunes: ‘The Lord bless you, righteous dwelling, holy mountain.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Judah and all its towns will live together in the land, along with farmers and those who follow the flock.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I’ll provide abundance for those who are weary, and fill all who are faint.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then I awoke and looked around, and I had had a pleasant sleep.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Look, days are coming,” declares the Lord, “when I’ll sow the house of Israel and the house of Judah using people and animals as seed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Just as I’ve watched over them to pull up, tear down, overthrow, destroy, and bring disaster, so I’ll watch over them to build and to plant,” declares the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “In those days people will no longer say, ‘The fathers have eaten sour grapes, but the children’s teeth have been set on edge.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Instead, each person will die for his own iniquity. Everyone who eats sour grapes will have his own teeth set on edge.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Look, days are coming,” declares the Lord, “when I’ll make a new covenant with the house of Israel and the house of Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It won’t be like the covenant I made with their ancestors on the day I took them by the hand to bring them out of the land of Egypt. They broke my covenant, although I was a husband to them,” declares the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Rather, this is the covenant that I’ll make with the house of Israel after those days,” declares the Lord. “I’ll put my Law within them and will write it on their hearts. I’ll be their God and they will be my people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: No longer will a person teach his neighbor or his relative: ‘Know the Lord.’ Instead, they’ll all know me, from the least to the greatest of them,” declares the Lord. “Indeed, I’ll forgive their iniquity, and I’ll remember their sin no more.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This is what the Lord says,
    who gives the sun for light by day,
the laws that govern the moon and stars for light by night,
    and who stirs up the sea so that its waves roar.
        The Lord of the Heavenly Armies is his name:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“If these laws cease to function in my presence,”
    declares the Lord,
“then the descendants of Israel will cease to be
    a nation in my presence for all time!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This is what the Lord says:
“If the heavens could be measured above,
    or the foundations of the earth be searched out below,
then I also would reject all the descendants of Israel
    because of everything they have done,”
        declares the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Look, days are coming,” declares the Lord, “when the city of the Lord will be rebuilt from the Tower of Hananel to the Corner Gate.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: A measuring line will go straight out from there to the hill of Gareb, and then it will turn to Goah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The whole valley of dead bodies and ashes and all the fields as far as the Brook Kidron to the corner of the Horse Gate toward the east will be holy to the Lord. It won’t be uprooted or overthrown again, forever.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is the message that came to Jeremiah from the Lord in the tenth year of the reign of Zedekiah, king of Judah. It was the eighteenth year of the reign of Nebuchadnezzar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The army of the king of Babylon was then besieging Jerusalem, and Jeremiah the prophet was confined in the courtyard of the guard at the palace of the king of Judah
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: where Zedekiah had confined him. Zedekiah had said, “Why did you prophesy and say these things? You said, ‘This is what the Lord says: “I’m about to give this city into the hand of the king of Babylon, and he will capture it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Zedekiah, king of Judah, won’t escape from the Chaldeans, for he has surely been given over to the king of Babylon. He will speak to him face to face and look at him eye to eye.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king of Babylon will take Zedekiah to Babylon and there he will stay until I judge him,” declares the Lord. “If you fight against the Chaldeans, you won’t succeed.”’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jeremiah replied, “This message from the Lord came to me:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Look, Hanamel, your cousin, is coming to you and will say, “Buy my field in Anathoth for yourself, because the right of redemption to buy it belongs to you.”’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Then my cousin Hanamel came to me in the courtyard of the guard just as the Lord had said, and he told me, ‘Please buy my field in Anathoth in the territory of Benjamin because you have the right to possess it, and the right to redeem it belongs to you. Buy it for yourself.’ So I knew that this was a message from the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Then I bought the field in Anathoth from my cousin Hanamel. I weighed out the silver for him—seventeen shekels of silver.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I signed the deed and sealed it. I called in witnesses and used scales to weigh out the silver.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then I took the deed of purchase—both the sealed one with the terms and conditions and the open one—
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and I gave the deed of purchase to Neriah’s son Baruch, the grandson of Mahseiah, in the presence of my cousin Hanamel, in the presence of the witnesses who signed the deed of purchase, and in the presence of all the Judeans sitting in the courtyard of the guard.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In their presence, I instructed Baruch as follows:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘This is what the Lord of the Heavenly Armies, the God of Israel, says: “Take these deeds—both this sealed deed of purchase and this open deed—and put them in a clay pot so they’ll last for a long time.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For this is what the Lord of the Heavenly Armies, the God of Israel, says: ‘Houses, fields, and vineyards will again be bought in this land.’”’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “After I had given the deed of purchase to Neriah’s son Baruch, I prayed to the Lord:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Lord! Look, you made the heavens and the earth with your great power and your outstretched arm. Nothing is too difficult for you!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You, the great God, the mighty one, show gracious love to thousands and repay the parents’ iniquity to their children after them. The Lord of the Heavenly Armies is his name.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You are great in regards to your purposes and mighty in regards to your works. Your eyes are open to everything that people do, and will reward each one according to their ways and just as their actions deserve.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You are the one who performed signs and wonders in the land of Egypt and continue to do so until this day, both in Israel and among the rest of humanity. You made a reputation for yourself that continues to this day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: By your strong hand and outstretched arm, and with great terror, you brought your people Israel out of the land of Egypt with signs and wonders.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And you gave them this land which you had promised their ancestors that you would give them—a land flowing with milk and honey.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They came and took possession of it, but they didn’t obey you or walk according to your Law. They didn’t do what you commanded them to do, so you caused all this calamity to happen to them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Look, the siege ramps have reached the city to take it. Because of the sword, famine, and plague, the city has been given over to the Chaldeans who are fighting against it. What you said has happened, and you are watching it occur!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Lord, you have told me, “Buy the field for yourself with money and call in witnesses,” even though the city is being given over to the Chaldeans.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then this message from the Lord came to Jeremiah:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Look, I am the Lord, the God who rules over all flesh. Is anything too difficult for me?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Therefore, this is what the Lord says: “I’m about to give this city into the hands of the Chaldeans and Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylon, and he will capture it.
verses.speaker: Narrator
