verses.text: The Chaldeans who are fighting against this city will come, set this city on fire, and burn it along with the houses on whose roofs incense was burned to Baal and liquid offerings were poured out to other gods in order to provoke me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Indeed, the Israelis and Judeans have been doing only evil in my presence since their youth. Indeed, the Israelis have done nothing but provoke me by what they have made with their hands,” declares the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Indeed, this city has provoked me to anger and wrath from the day they built it until now, and so I’ll remove it from my sight
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: because of all the evil that the Israelis and Judeans have done to provoke me. They, their kings, their officials, their priests, their prophets, the people of Judah, and those living in Jerusalem have done these things.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They have turned their backs to me rather than their faces. Even though I taught them, teaching them again and again, they didn’t listen to accept correction.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They put their detestable idols in the house that is called by my name and defiled it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They built the high places of Baal that are in the Hinnom Valley in order to sacrifice their sons and daughters to Molech—something that I didn’t command, nor did it ever enter my mind for them to require this utterly repugnant thing—and lead Judah into sin.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Now therefore,” says the Lord God of Israel, “concerning this city about which you are saying, ‘It is being given into the control of the king of Babylon by sword, famine, and plague,’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I’m about to gather my people from all the lands where I’ve driven them in my anger, wrath, and great indignation. I’ll bring them back to this place and let them live in safety.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They’ll be my people, and I’ll be their God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I’ll give them one heart and one lifestyle so they’ll fear me always for their own good and for the good of their descendants after them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I’ll make an everlasting covenant with them that I won’t turn away from doing good for them. I’ll put the fear of me in their hearts so they won’t turn away from me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I’ll rejoice over them to do good for them, and I’ll faithfully plant them in this land with all my heart and soul.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Indeed, this is what the Lord says: ‘Just as I’m bringing all this great disaster on this people, so I’ll bring on them all the good things that I’m promising concerning them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Fields will be bought in this land about which you will say, “It is a desolate place without people or animals. It is given into the hands of the Chaldeans.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: People will buy fields for money, sign deeds, seal them, and call witnesses in the land of Benjamin, in the areas around Jerusalem, in the towns of Judah, the towns of the hill country, the towns of the Shephelah, and the towns of the Negev, for I’ll restore their fortunes,’ declares the Lord.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This message from the Lord came to Jeremiah a second time while he was still confined in the courtyard of the guard:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “This is what the Lord says who made the earth, the Lord who formed it in order to establish it—whose name is the Lord—
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Call to me and I’ll answer you, and will tell you about great and hidden things that you don’t know.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For this is what the Lord God of Israel says about the houses of this city and the houses of the kings of Judah that were torn down to defend against the siege ramps and the sword,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘The Chaldeans are coming to fight and to fill those houses with the dead bodies of the people that I’ve struck down in my anger and wrath, for I’ve hidden my face from this city because of all their wickedness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “‘Look, I’ll bring restoration and healing to it, and I’ll heal them. I’ll reveal to them an abundance of peace and faithfulness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I’ll restore the security of Judah and Israel and rebuild them as they were at first.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I’ll cleanse them from all their sin that they have committed against me, and I’ll forgive all their sins that they committed against me and by which they rebelled against me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jerusalem will be for me a name of joy, praise, and glory to all the nations of the earth that hear about all the good that I’m doing for them. They’ll fear and tremble because of all the good and because of all the peace that I’m bringing to Jerusalem.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “This is what the Lord says: ‘You are saying about this place, “It is a ruin without people and without animals.” Yet in the cities of Judah and the streets of Jerusalem which are desolate places without inhabitants and without animals, there will again be heard
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
the sounds of rejoicing and gladness, the sounds of the bridegroom and the bride, and the sounds of those saying,
“Give thanks to the Lord of the Heavenly Armies,
    for the Lord is good,
        and his gracious love lasts forever,”
as they bring thanksgiving offerings to the Lord’s Temple. For I’ll restore the fortunes of the land as they were at first,’ declares the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “This is what the Lord of the Heavenly Armies says: ‘In this place that is now a ruin without people or animals, and in all its towns there will again be pasture for shepherds resting their flocks.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the towns of the hill country, in the towns of the Shephelah, in the towns of the Negev, in the territory of Benjamin, in the areas around Jerusalem, and in the towns of Judah flocks will again pass under the hands of the one who counts them,’ says the Lord.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “‘Look, the time is coming,’ declares the Lord, ‘when I’ll fulfill the good promise that I spoke concerning the house of Israel and Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In those days and at that time I’ll cause a righteous Branch to spring up for David, and he will uphold justice and righteousness in the land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At that time Judah will be delivered and Jerusalem will dwell in safety. And this is the name people will call it, “The Lord is Our Righteousness.”’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For this is what the Lord says: ‘David will never be without a man sitting on the throne of the house of Israel,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: nor will the Levitical priests be without a man offering up burnt offerings, bringing in grain offerings, and offering sacrifices continuously before me.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This message from the Lord came to Jeremiah:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “This is what the Lord says: ‘If you could break my covenant with the day and night so that day and night wouldn’t occur at the proper time,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: then my covenant with my servant David might also be broken so that he wouldn’t have a son sitting on his throne, and so also with my servants the Levitical priests.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As the heavenly bodies cannot be counted, and the sands of the sea cannot be measured, so I’ll multiply the descendants of my servant David and the descendants of Levi who serve me.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This message from the Lord came to Jeremiah:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Haven’t you noticed what these people have been saying?—‘The Lord rejected the two families that he had chosen!’ They have contempt for my people and no longer consider them a nation.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is what the Lord says: ‘If I had not established my covenant for day and night and the laws that govern the heavens and earth,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: then I might reject the descendants of Jacob and my servant David by not taking some of his descendants as rulers over the descendants of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob. Indeed, I’ll restore their fortunes, and I’ll have compassion on them.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is the message that came to Jeremiah from the Lord while king Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon, all his army, all the kingdoms of the earth that were under his authority, along with all the people were fighting against Jerusalem and all its towns:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “This is what the Lord God of Israel says: ‘Go and speak to king Zedekiah of Judah. Say to him, “This is what the Lord says: ‘Look, I’m giving this city into the hand of the king of Babylon, and he will set it on fire.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You won’t escape from him. You will certainly be captured and given into his control. You will see the king of Babylon eye to eye, he will speak to you face to face, and you will go to Babylon.’”’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Yet, hear this message from the Lord, king Zedekiah of Judah. This is what the Lord says to you, ‘You won’t die by the sword.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You will die peacefully, and as they burned fires for your ancestors, the former kings who were before you, so they’ll burn fires for you, wailing, “Oh how terrible, your majesty!”’ For I’ve spoken the message,” declares the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Jeremiah the prophet spoke all of this in Jerusalem to king Zedekiah of Judah,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: while the army of the king of Babylon was fighting against Jerusalem and all the cities of Judah that were left, namely Lachish and Azekah. (They were the only fortified cities that remained among the cities of Judah.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is this message from the Lord that came to Jeremiah from the Lord after Zedekiah had made a covenant with all the people in Jerusalem proclaiming release for them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Each person was to set free his male and female slaves who were Hebrews, so that no Jewish person would enslave his brother.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the officials and all the people who had entered into the covenant agreed that each would set his male and female slaves free so that they would not enslave them any longer. They obeyed and they released them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But afterward they turned around and took back the male and female slaves that they had set free, and they forced them to become male and female slaves.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then this message from the Lord came to Jeremiah from the Lord:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “This is what the Lord God of Israel says: ‘I made a covenant with your ancestors on the day I brought them out of the land of Egypt, out of the house of slavery. I told them:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “At the end of seven years, each of you is to set free your fellow Hebrew who has sold himself to you and has served you for six years. You are to send him out from you with no further obligation.” But your ancestors didn’t obey me or pay attention.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You recently repented and did what was right in my eyes by proclaiming release for one another, and you made a covenant before me in the house that is called by my name.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But then you turned around and profaned my name when each of you took back his male and female slaves whom you had set free according to their desire, and you forced them to become male and female slaves.”’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Therefore, this is what the Lord says: ‘You haven’t obeyed me by each of you proclaiming a release for your brothers and neighbors. Now I’m going to proclaim a release for you,’ declares the Lord, ‘a release to the sword, to plague, and to famine, and I’ll make you a horrifying sight to all the kingdoms of the earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I’ll give over the men who transgressed my covenant, who haven’t fulfilled the terms of the covenant that they made before me when they cut the calf in two and passed between its parts—
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the officials of Judah, the officials of Jerusalem, the eunuchs, the priests, and all the people of the land who passed between the parts of the calf.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I’ll give them to their enemies who are seeking to kill them, and their dead bodies will be food for the birds of the sky and the animals of the land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I’ll give Zedekiah, king of Judah, and his officials into the domination of their enemies, to those who are seeking to kill them, and to the army of the king of Babylon that is coming against them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Look, I’m in command of them,’ declares the Lord, ‘and I’ll bring them back to this city. They’ll capture it and burn it with fire, and I’ll turn the towns of Judah into desolate places without inhabitants.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is the message that came to Jeremiah from the Lord during the reign of Josiah’s son Jehoiakim, king of Judah:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Go to the house of the Rechabites and speak to them. Bring them into the Lord’s Temple, to one of the offices, and offer them wine to drink.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So I took Jeremiah’s son Jaazaniah (a descendant of Habazziniah), his brothers, all his sons, and the whole family of the Rechabites.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I brought them to the Lord’s Temple to the office of the descendants of Igdaliah’s son Hanan, the man of God, which was next to the office of the officials, and which was above the office of Shallum’s son Maaseiah, the keeper of the threshold.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I put containers full of wine and cups in front of the members of the Rechabite clan and told them, “Drink the wine!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But they said, “We won’t drink wine, because our ancestor, Rechab’s son Jonadab commanded us: ‘You and your descendants are never to drink wine!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You aren’t to build houses, you aren’t to sow seeds, and you aren’t to plant vineyards, or own them. Instead, you are to live in tents all your lives, so you will enjoy a long life in the land where you reside.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We have obeyed everything that our ancestor, Rechab’s son Jonadab, commanded us. So we, our wives, our sons, and our daughters have drunk no wine all our lives,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and have built no houses to live in. We don’t have vineyards, fields, or seed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We have lived in tents. We have obeyed and have done everything that our ancestor Jonadab commanded us.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now when Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon came up against the land, we said, ‘Come on! Let’s go to Jerusalem because of the army of the Chaldeans and the army of Aram. And now we’re living in Jerusalem.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This message from the Lord came to Jeremiah:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “This is what the Lord of the Heavenly Armies, the God of Israel says: ‘Go and say to the people of Judah and the inhabitants of Jerusalem, “Will you not accept correction by listening to what I say?” declares the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “But what Rechab’s son Jonadab commanded his sons about not drinking wine is observed, and they haven’t drunk wine until this day. Indeed, they obey the commands of their ancestor. But I’ve spoken to you again and again, and you haven’t obeyed me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I’ve sent you all my servants, the prophets, sending them again and again. I’ve said, ‘Each of you turn from his evil behavior and make your deeds right. Don’t follow other gods to serve them. Then you will remain in the land that I gave to you and to your ancestors.’ But you haven’t paid attention and you haven’t obeyed me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Indeed the descendants of Rechab’s son Jonadab have carried out the command of their ancestor that he gave them, but this people has not obeyed me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Therefore, this is what the Lord God of the Heavenly Armies, the God of Israel says: “Look, I’m bringing on Judah and all the residents of Jerusalem all the disaster that I pronounced against them, because I spoke to them, but they didn’t listen, and I called out to them, but they didn’t answer.”’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Jeremiah told the house of the Rechabites, “This is what the Lord God of the Heavenly Armies, the God of Israel says: ‘Because you obeyed the commandment of your ancestor Jonadab, have observed all his commandments, and have done everything that he commanded you,’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: therefore, this is what the Lord God of the Heavenly Armies, the God of Israel says: ‘Rechab’s son Jonadab won’t lack a descendant who serves me always.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the fourth year of the reign of Josiah’s son King Jehoiakim of Judah, this message came to Jeremiah from the Lord:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Take a scroll and write on it all the words that I’ve spoken to you about Israel, about Judah, and about all the nations, since I first spoke to you in the time of Josiah until the present time.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Perhaps the house of Judah will hear about all the calamity that I’m planning to bring on them, and so each of them will turn from his wicked way and I’ll forgive their iniquities and sins.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jeremiah summoned Neriah’s son Baruch and at Jeremiah’s dictation, Baruch wrote on the scroll all the words of the Lord that he had spoken to him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jeremiah instructed Baruch, “I’m confined and can’t go to the Lord’s Temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You go and read the words of the Lord that you wrote at my dictation from the scroll. Read them to the people at the Lord’s Temple on the fast day. Also read them to all the people of Judah who are coming from their towns.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Perhaps their pleas for help will come to the Lord’s attention, and each of them will turn from his evil lifestyle in light of the great anger and wrath that the Lord has declared against this people.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Neriah’s son Baruch did just as Jeremiah the prophet instructed him, reading the words of the Lord from the scroll at the Lord’s Temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the ninth month of the fifth year of the reign of Josiah’s son Jehoiakim, king of Judah, a fast was proclaimed in the Lord’s presence in Jerusalem for all the people of Jerusalem, as well as all the people who were coming from the towns of Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Baruch read the words of Jeremiah from the scroll to all the people at the Lord’s Temple. He did this from the office of Shaphan’s son Gemariah the scribe, in the upper court at the entrance of the New Gate of the Lord’s Temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Gemariah’s son Micaiah, the grandson of Shaphan, heard all the words of the Lord from the scroll,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: he went down to the palace, to the scribe’s office, where all the officials were sitting. Elishama the scribe, Shemaiah’s son Delaiah, Achbor’s son Elnathan, Shaphan’s son Gemariah, Hananiah’s son Zedekiah, and all the other officials were there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Micaiah told them all the things that he had heard when Baruch read from the scroll to the people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then all the officials sent Nethaniah’s son Jehudi, (who was also the grandson of Shelemiah and Cushi’s great-grandson), to Baruch, who said, “Take the scroll that you read to the people and come.” Neriah’s son Baruch took the scroll with him and went to them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They told him, “Please sit down and read it to us.” So Baruch read it to them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they heard all the words, they turned to one another in fear, saying to Baruch, “We must report all these things to the king.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then they asked Baruch, “Please tell us how you wrote all the words. Did Jeremiah dictate them all?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Baruch answered them, “Yes, Jeremiah dictated all these words to me, and I wrote them in the scroll with ink.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the officials told Baruch, “Go, hide yourself, both you and Jeremiah, and don’t let anyone know where you are.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The officials went to the king in the courtyard, but they deposited the scroll in the office of Elishama the scribe. Then they reported everything written on the scroll to the king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king sent Jehudi to get the scroll, and he took it from the office of Elishama the scribe. Jehudi read it to the king and to all the officials who were standing beside the king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king was sitting in the winter palace in the ninth month and a stove was burning in front of him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As Jehudi would read three or four columns, the king would cut it with a scribe’s knife and throw it into the fire which was in the stove, until all the scroll was burned in the fire in the stove.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king and all his officials who were listening to these words were not afraid, nor did they tear their garments.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Even though Elnathan, Delaiah, and Gemariah urged the king not to burn the scroll, he would not listen to them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king ordered his son Jerahmeel, Azriel’s son Seraiah, and Abdeel’s son Shelemiah to get Baruch the scribe and Jeremiah the prophet, but the Lord had hidden them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This message from the Lord came to Jeremiah after the king burned the scroll containing the words that Baruch had written at Jeremiah’s dictation:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Go back, take another scroll and write on it all the original words which were on the scroll that Jehoiakim, king of Judah, burned.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Concerning Jehoiakim, king of Judah, you are to say, ‘This is what the Lord says: “You burned this scroll, all the while saying, ‘Why did you write on it that the king of Babylon will definitely come, destroy this land, and eliminate both people and animals from it?’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Therefore, this is what the Lord says concerning Jehoiakim, king of Judah, “He will have no one to sit on the throne of David, and his corpse will be thrown out to rot during the heat of the day and the frost of the night.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I’ll punish him, his descendants, and his officials for their iniquity. I’ll bring on them, on the residents of Jerusalem, and on the men of Judah all the calamity about which I’ve warned them, but they would not listen.”’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Jeremiah took another scroll and gave it to Neriah’s son Baruch the scribe. He wrote on it, at Jeremiah’s dictation, all the words of the book that Jehoiakim king of Judah burned in the fire. He also added to them many similar words.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Josiah’s son King Zedekiah reigned in place of Jehoiakim’s son Coniah, whom Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon had made king of the land of Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But neither he nor his officials nor the people of the land listened to the words of the Lord that were spoken by Jeremiah the prophet.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Zedekiah sent Shelemiah’s son Jehucal and Maaseiah’s son Zephaniah the priest to Jeremiah the prophet, asking him, “Please pray to the Lord our God for us.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Jeremiah was still going in and out among the people since he had not yet been put in prison.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pharaoh’s army had come out of Egypt, and when the Chaldeans who were besieging Jerusalem heard the report about them, they withdrew from Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then this message from the Lord came to Jeremiah the prophet:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “This is what the Lord God of Israel says: ‘This is what you are to say to the king of Judah who sent you to me to inquire of me, “Look, Pharaoh’s army that has come to help will go back to its own land of Egypt,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and then the Chaldeans will come back to fight against this city, to capture it, and burn it with fire.”’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “This is what the Lord says: ‘Don’t deceive yourselves by saying, “The Chaldeans will surely go away from us,” ‘for they won’t go.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Indeed, even if you defeated the entire Chaldean army that is fighting against you, and they had only wounded men left in their tents, they would get up and burn this city with fire.’”’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the Chaldean army was leaving Jerusalem because of Pharaoh’s army,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jeremiah left Jerusalem to go to the territory of Benjamin to take possession of his property there among the people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He was in the Gate of Benjamin, and chief officer Irijah, Shelemiah’s son and the grandson of Hananiah, was there. He arrested Jeremiah the prophet, accusing him: “You are going over to the Chaldeans!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jeremiah said, “It’s a lie! I’m not going over to the Chaldeans.” But Irijah would not listen to him, and he arrested Jeremiah and brought him to the officials.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The officials were angry with Jeremiah and beat him. They put him in jail in the house of Jonathan the scribe because they had made it into a prison.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Jeremiah came into the cells in the dungeon and remained there for a long time.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then King Zedekiah sent for Jeremiah and received him. The king questioned him secretly in his house: “Is there a message from the Lord?”
Jeremiah said, “There is,” and then he said, “You will be given into the hand of the king of Babylon.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Jeremiah asked King Zedekiah, “What offense have I committed against you, your officials, or these people that you have put me in prison?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Where are your prophets who prophesied to you, telling you: ‘The king of Babylon won’t come against you or against this land’?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now, please listen, your majesty, and pay attention to what I’m asking you. Don’t make me go back to the house of Jonathan the scribe, so I don’t die there.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So King Zedekiah gave the order, and they assigned Jeremiah to the courtyard of the guard. Each day they gave him a loaf of bread from the bakers’ street until all the bread in the city was gone. So Jeremiah remained in the courtyard of the guard.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Mattan’s son Shephatiah, Pashhur’s son Gedaliah, Shelemiah’s son Jucal, and Malchijah’s son Pashhur heard the words that Jeremiah was speaking to all the people:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “This is what the Lord says: ‘Whoever stays in this city will die by the sword, by famine, and by the plague, but the one who goes over to the Chaldeans will live. His life will be spared, and he will live.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is what the Lord says: ‘This city will surely be given to the army of the king of Babylon, and he will capture it.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the officials told the king, “Let this man be put to death because he’s undermining the efforts of the soldiers who remain in this city and that of all the people by speaking words like these to them. Indeed, this man is not seeking the well-being of this people, but rather their harm.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Zedekiah said, “Look, he’s in your hands, and the king can do nothing to you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they threw Jeremiah into a cistern that belonged to the king’s son Malchijah and was located in the courtyard of the guard. When they let Jeremiah down with ropes, because there was no water in the cistern—only mud—Jeremiah sank into the mud.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ebed-melech the Ethiopian, a eunuch in the king’s house, heard that Jeremiah had been put in the cistern. The king was sitting in the Benjamin Gate,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: so Ebed-melech went out of the palace and spoke to the king:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Your majesty, these men have acted wickedly in all they have done to the prophet Jeremiah by throwing him into the cistern. He will die where he is because of the famine since there is no more bread in the city.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the king ordered Ebed-melech the Ethiopian: “Thirty men are at your disposal. Take them with you and bring up Jeremiah the prophet from the cistern before he dies.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Ebed-melech took the men with him and went to the palace, underneath the storeroom. He took worn out rags and worn out clothes from there, and using ropes he lowered them down to Jeremiah in the cistern.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ebed-melech the Ethiopian told Jeremiah, “Put the worn out rags and clothes under your armpits under the ropes,” and Jeremiah did as he said.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They pulled Jeremiah with the ropes and brought him up from the cistern, but Jeremiah remained in the courtyard of the guard.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Zedekiah sent for Jeremiah the prophet and had him brought to him at the third entrance to the Lord’s Temple. The king told Jeremiah, “I’m going to ask you something, and don’t hide anything from me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jeremiah told Zedekiah, “When I tell you, you will surely put me to death, won’t you? And when I give you advice, you don’t listen to me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then King Zedekiah, in secret, swore an oath to Jeremiah: “As surely as the Lord lives, who gave us this life to live, I won’t have you put to death, nor will I hand you over to these men who are seeking to kill you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Jeremiah told Zedekiah, “This is what the Lord God of the Heavenly Armies, the God of Israel, says: ‘If you will immediately surrender to the officers of the king of Babylon, then you will live, and this city won’t be burned with fire. Both you and your family will live.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But if you don’t surrender to the officers of the king of Babylon, then this city will be given to the Chaldeans, and they’ll burn it with fire. You won’t escape from their hands.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then King Zedekiah told Jeremiah, “I’m afraid of the Judeans who have gone over to the Chaldeans. The Chaldeans may turn me over to them, and they may treat me harshly.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jeremiah said, “They won’t turn you over. Obey the Lord in what I’m telling you, and it will go well for you and you will live.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But if you refuse to surrender, this is what the Lord has shown me:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Look, all the women who are left in the house of the king of Judah will be brought out to the officers of the king of Babylon, and will say,
‘These friends of yours have mislead you
    and overcome you.
Your feet have sunk down into the mire,
    but they have turned away.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “They’ll bring all your women and children out to the Chaldeans, and you won’t escape from their hand. Indeed, you will be seized by the hand of the king of Babylon, and this city will be burned with fire.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Zedekiah told Jeremiah, “Don’t let anyone know about these words and you won’t die.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If the officials hear that I’ve spoken with you, and they come to you and say, ‘Tell us what you told the king, and what the king told you; don’t hide it from us, and we won’t put you to death,’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: then you are to say to them, ‘I was presenting my request to the king that I not be taken back to the house of Jonathan to die there.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When all the officials came to Jeremiah and questioned him, he replied to them exactly as the king had ordered him. So they stopped speaking with him because the conversation had not been overheard.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jeremiah remained in the courtyard of the guard until the day Jerusalem was captured.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is how Jerusalem was captured: In the tenth month of the ninth year of the reign of Zedekiah king of Judah, Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon and all his army came to Jerusalem and laid siege to it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On the ninth day of the fourth month, in the eleventh year of the reign of Zedekiah, the wall of the city was breached.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the officials of the king of Babylon came and sat in the Middle Gate, including Nergal-sarri-usur, governor of Sinmagir, Nabu-sarrussu-ukin the high official, Nergal-sarri-user, the chief official, and all the rest of the officials of the king of Babylon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Zedekiah king of Judah and all the soldiers saw them, they fled and went out of the city at night through the king’s garden through the gate between the two walls. Then he went out on the road toward the Arabah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Chaldean army pursued them and overtook Zedekiah on the plains of Jericho. When they seized him they brought him to Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon at Riblah in the land of Hamath, and he passed judgment on him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At Riblah, the king of Babylon executed Zedekiah’s sons right before his eyes. He also executed all the nobles of Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he put out Zedekiah’s eyes and bound him with bronze fetters to take him to Babylon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Chaldeans burned the palace and the houses of the people with fire, and they broke down the walls of Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Nebuzaradan, the captain of the Babylonian guard, took into exile in Babylon the rest of the people who remained in the city, those who had deserted to Nebuchadnezzar, and the rest of the people who remained.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Nebuzaradan the captain of the guard left in the land of Judah some of the poor people who did not have anything, and he gave them vineyards and fields on that day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon gave orders concerning Jeremiah through Nebuzaradan, the captain of the guard:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Take him, look after him, and don’t do anything to harm him. Rather, do for him whatever he tells you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Nebuzaradan, the captain of the guard, Nebushazban, the high official, Nergal-sar-ezer, the chief official, and all the officials of the king of Babylon sent for Jeremiah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They sent for Jeremiah and took him from the courtyard of the guard. They handed him over to Ahikam’s son Gedaliah, the grandson of Shaphan, to take him home. So he remained among the people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This message from the Lord came to Jeremiah while he was confined in the courtyard of the guard:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Go and speak to Ebed-melech the Ethiopian: ‘This is what the Lord of the Heavenly Armies, the God of Israel, says: “Look, I’m going to fulfill my promise against this city for disaster rather than for good, and on that day it will happen before your eyes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But I’ll deliver you on that day,” declares the Lord. “You won’t be given into the hands of the men you fear.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For I’ll surely deliver you, and you won’t fall by the sword. Your life will be spared because you trusted me,” declares the Lord.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is the message that came to Jeremiah from the Lord after Nebuzaradan the captain of the guard had released him from Ramah, when he was bound in chains, along with all the exiles from Jerusalem and Judah who were being taken into exile in Babylon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The captain of the guard took Jeremiah and told him, “The Lord your God has predicted this disaster on this place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And now the Lord has brought it about and has done just as he said. Because you people sinned against the Lord and didn’t obey him, this has happened to you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now, look, I’ve freed you today from the chains that were on your hands. If you want to come with me to Babylon, come, and I’ll look after you. But if you don’t want to come with me to Babylon, don’t. Look, the whole land lies before you, so go wherever it seems good and right for you to go.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When he still did not respond, Nebuzaradan said, “Return to Ahikam’s son Gedaliah, whom the king of Babylon has appointed over the cities of Judah, and remain with him among the people—or go wherever it seems right for you to go.” Then the captain of the guard gave him an allowance of food and a gift and sent him off.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jeremiah came to Ahikam’s son Gedaliah at Mizpah, and he remained with him among the people who were left in the land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the leaders of the forces who were in the field along with their men heard that the king of Babylon had appointed Ahikam’s son Gedaliah over the men, women, children, and the poor of the land who had not been taken into exile in Babylon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Those who came to Gedaliah at Mizpah included Nethaniah’s son Ishmael, Jonathan, Kareah’s son Jonathan, Tanhumeth’s son Seraiah, Ephai’s sons from Netophah; and Jezaniah, the son of a man from Maacah. They came along with their men.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ahikam’s son Gedaliah, the grandson of Shaphan, swore an oath to them and their men: “Don’t be afraid to serve the Chaldeans. Remain in the land and serve the king of Babylon, and things will go well for you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As for me, I’ll remain at Mizpah to represent you before the Chaldeans who come to us. As for you, gather wine, summer fruit, and oil. Put it in your containers and live in your cities that you have taken over.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the Judeans who were in Moab, those with the people in Ammon, those in Edom, and those in all the other countries also heard that the king of Babylon had left a remnant for Judah and that he had appointed Ahikam’s son Gedaliah, the grandson of Shaphan, over them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So all the Judeans returned from all the countries where they had been scattered. They came to the land of Judah, to Gedaliah at Mizpah, and they gathered wine and summer fruit in great abundance.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Kareah’s son Jonathan and all leaders of the forces who were in the field came to Gedaliah at Mizpah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They told him, “Are you aware that Baalis, the king of the people of Ammon, has sent Nethaniah’s son Ishmael to take your life?” But Ahikam’s son Gedaliah did not believe them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Kareah’s son Jonathan spoke privately to Gedaliah at Mizpah: “Let me go kill Nethaniah’s son Ishmael, and no one will know. Why should he take your life? Otherwise all the Judeans who have gathered around you will be scattered, and the remnant of Judah will perish.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ahikam’s son Gedaliah replied to Kareah’s son Jonathan, “Don’t do this! You’re lying about Ishmael!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the seventh month, Nethaniah’s son Ishmael, the grandson of Elishama, a member of the royal family and one of the chief officers of the king, came to Ahikam’s son Gedaliah at Mizpah, along with ten men. While they were dining together there at Mizpah,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Nethaniah’s son Ishmael and the ten men with him got up and killed Ahikam’s son Gedaliah, the grandson of Shaphan, with swords and killed the man whom the king of Babylon had appointed over the land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ishmael also struck down all the Judeans who were with him (that is, with Gedaliah) at Mizpah, along with the Chaldean soldiers who were found there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now on the day after Gedaliah was killed, when as yet no one knew about it,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: eighty men from Shechem, from Shiloh, and from Samaria came with their beards shaved, their clothes torn, and their bodies slashed. They had grain offerings and incense with them to present at the Lord’s Temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Nethaniah’s son Ishmael went out from Mizpah to meet them, crying as he went. As he met them he told them, “Come meet with Ahikam’s son Gedaliah.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they reached the middle of the city, Nethaniah’s son Ishmael and the men who were with him slaughtered them and threw them into a cistern.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ten men who were among them told Ishmael, “Don’t kill us, because we have stores of wheat, barley, oil, and honey hidden in the field.” So Ishmael stopped and did not kill them or their companions.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ishmael threw the bodies of the men he killed on account of Gedaliah into the cistern that King Asa had made for protection against King Baasha of Israel. That is the same one Nethaniah’s son Ishmael filled with those he killed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Ishmael took captive all the rest of the people who were in Mizpah, including the king’s daughters and all the rest of the people in Mizpah over whom Nebuzaradan the captain of the guard had appointed Ahikam’s son Gedaliah. Nethaniah’s son Ishmael took them captive and then set out to cross over to the Ammonites.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Kareah’s son Jonathan and all the military leaders who were with him heard about all the terrible things that Nethaniah’s son Ishmael had done.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they took all the men and went to fight Nethaniah’s son Ishmael, and they found him at the large pool that is at Gibeon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When all the people who were with Ishmael saw Kareah’s son Jonathan and all the military leaders who were with him, they were glad.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the people whom Ishmael had taken captive from Mizpah turned around and went back to Kareah’s son Jonathan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Nethaniah’s son Ishmael and eight other men escaped from Jonathan and went to the Ammonites.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Kareah’s son Jonathan and all the military leaders who were with him took all the rest of the people from Mizpah whom he had rescued from Nethaniah’s son Ishmael after he had killed Ahikam’s son Gedaliah, including the young men, the soldiers, women, children, and eunuchs whom he had rescued from Gibeon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They traveled and then stopped at Geruth Chimham near Bethlehem on their way to Egypt
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: because of the Chaldeans. They were afraid of the Chaldeans because Nethaniah’s son Ishmael had killed Ahikam’s son Gedaliah, whom the king of Babylon had appointed over the land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then all the military leaders, Kareah’s son Jonathan, Hoshaiah’s son Jezaniah, and all the people from the least to the greatest approached Jeremiah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They told Jeremiah the prophet, “Please listen to what we have to ask of you. Pray to the Lord your God for us and for all these survivors. Indeed, only a few of us remain out of many, as you can see.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pray that the Lord your God may inform us as to how we should live and what we should do.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jeremiah the prophet told them, “I’ve heard, and I’m going to pray to the Lord your God just as you have requested. Whatever the Lord answers, I’ll tell you. I won’t withhold anything from you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then they told Jeremiah, “May the Lord be a true and faithful witness against us if we don’t do everything that the Lord your God tells us through you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Whether it seems good or bad, we will obey the Lord our God to whom we send you, so it may go well for us. Indeed, we will obey the Lord our God.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At the end of ten days a message from the Lord came to Jeremiah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So he called Kareah’s son Jonathan, all the military leaders who were with him, and all the people from the least to the greatest.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He told them, “This is what the Lord God of Israel says, to whom you sent me to take your request:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘If you will just remain in this land, I’ll build you up and not pull you down. I’ll plant you and not uproot you, for I’m sorry about the disaster I’ve brought on you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Don’t be afraid of the king of Babylon as you have been. Don’t fear him,’ declares the Lord, ‘because I am with you to save you and deliver you from his control.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I’ll show you compassion, so he will have compassion on you and return you to your land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But if you disobey the Lord your God by saying, “We won’t stay in this land,”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and you also say, “No, but we will go to the land of Egypt where we won’t see war or hear the sound of the trumpet or hunger for bread, and there we will stay,”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: then hear this message from the Lord, remnant of Judah: ‘This is what the Lord of the Heavenly Armies, the God of Israel, says: “If you are really determined to go into Egypt, and you go there to settle,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the sword that you fear will overtake you there in the land of Egypt. The famine that you dread will pursue you into Egypt, and there you will die.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the people who are determined to go into Egypt to settle there will die by the sword, by famine, and by the plague. No one will survive the disaster that I’ll bring on them.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For this is what the Lord of the Heavenly Armies, the God of Israel, says: ‘Just as my anger and my wrath were poured out on the inhabitants of Jerusalem, so my wrath will be poured out on you when you enter Egypt. You will be a curse and an object of horror, ridicule, and scorn, and you will never again see this place.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord has told you, remnant of Judah, ‘Don’t go to Egypt!’ So be fully aware that I’ve warned you, today,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: that you have deceived yourselves. Indeed, you yourselves sent me to the Lord your God, saying, ‘Pray to the Lord your God for us, and whatever the Lord our God tells us we will do.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I’ve told you today, but you haven’t obeyed the Lord your God in all that he sent me to tell you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now, be fully aware that you will die by the sword, by famine, and by plague in the place where you want to settle.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Jeremiah had finished telling all the people all the words that the Lord their God had sent him to tell them—that is, all these words—
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hoshaiah’s son Azariah, Kareah’s son Johanan, and all the arrogant men told Jeremiah, “You’re lying! The Lord our God didn’t send you to say, ‘Don’t go to Egypt to settle there.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Indeed, Neriah’s son Baruch is inciting you against us in order to give us into the hands of the Chaldeans, to kill us, or to take us into exile to Babylon.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Kareah’s son Johanan, all the military leaders, and all the people did not obey the instructions given by the Lord to remain in the land of Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Kareah’s son Johanan and all the military leaders took the entire remnant of Judah that had returned from all the nations where they had been scattered to settle in the land of Judah—
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the young men, the women, the children, the daughters of the king, and everyone whom Nebuzaradan the captain of the guard had left with Ahikam’s son Gedaliah, the grandson of Shaphan, along with Jeremiah the prophet and Neriah’s son Baruch.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they went into the land of Egypt, because they did not obey the Lord, and they travelled as far as Tahpanhes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then this message from the Lord came to Jeremiah in Tahpanhes:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Take large stones in your hands, and, in the sight of the men of Judah, bury them in the mortar of the brickwork at the entrance of Pharaoh’s house in Tahpanhes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then say to them, ‘This is what the Lord of the Heavenly Armies, the God of Israel, says: “I’m going to send for my servant Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon. I’ll take him and set his throne over these stones that I’ve buried, and he will spread his canopy over them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He will come and attack the land of Egypt—those meant for death will be put to death, those meant for captivity will be taken captive, and those meant for the sword will be put to the sword.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He will set fire to the temples of the gods of Egypt. He will burn their idols and take them captive. He will wrap himself with the land of Egypt like a shepherd wraps himself with a garment, and then he will leave from there in peace.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He will shatter the pillars of Heliopolis in the land of Egypt and will burn the temples of the gods of Egypt with fire.”’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is the message that came to Jeremiah for all the Judeans who were living in the land of Egypt, who were living in Migdol, Tahpanhes, Memphis, and in the land of Pathros, saying,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “This is what the Lord of the Heavenly Armies, the God of Israel, says: ‘You have seen the disaster that I brought on Jerusalem and all the cities of Judah. Look, they’re in ruins today, with no one living in them,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: because of the wickedness that they did, provoking me to anger by continuing to offer sacrifices and worship other gods that neither they nor you nor your ancestors had known.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Yet I sent all my servants the prophets to you again and again, saying, “Don’t do this repulsive thing that I hate.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘But they didn’t listen or pay attention by turning from their wickedness and not offering sacrifices to other gods.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: My wrath and my anger were poured out, and they burned in the cities of Judah and the streets of Jerusalem so that they have become a ruin and a desolate place, as is the case today.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Now, this is what the Lord of the Heavenly Armies, the God of Israel, says: ‘Why are you doing great harm to yourselves so as to cut off from Judah man and woman, child and infant from you, leaving yourselves without a remnant?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And why have you provoked me to anger by the works of your hands, by offering sacrifices to other gods in the land of Egypt where you have come to settle so that you cut yourselves off and become an object of ridicule and scorn among all the nations of the earth?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Have you forgotten the evil deeds of your ancestors, the evil deeds of the kings of Judah, the evil deeds of their wives, your evil deeds, and the evil deeds of your wives, that they did in the land of Judah and the streets of Jerusalem?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: To this day they haven’t humbled themselves, they haven’t shown reverence for the Lord, and they haven’t lived according to my Law and my statutes that I set before them and before their ancestors.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Therefore, this is what the Lord of the Heavenly Armies, the God of Israel, says: ‘Look, I’ve determined to bring disaster on you and to cut off all Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I’ll take the remnant of Judah that determined to go to the land of Egypt to settle there, and all of them will come to an end in the land of Egypt. They’ll fall by the sword, and they’ll come to an end by famine. They’ll become a curse, an object of horror, ridicule, and scorn.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I’ll punish those who live in the land of Egypt just as I punished Jerusalem—with the sword, with famine, and with plague.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Of the remnant of Judah that came into the land of Egypt to settle there, no one will escape or survive to return to the land of Judah where they long to return and live. Indeed, they won’t return, except for some refugees.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then all the men who knew that their wives were offering sacrifices to other gods and all the women who were standing by—a large group, including all the people who were living in the land of Egypt in Pathros—answered Jeremiah:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “As for the message that you reported to us in the name of the Lord, we won’t listen to you!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Rather, we will keep doing everything that we said we would by offering sacrifices to the Queen of Heaven and by pouring out liquid offerings to her just as we, our ancestors, our kings, and our leaders did in the cities of Judah and the streets of Jerusalem. Then we had plenty of bread, things went well for us, and we didn’t experience disaster.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: From the time we stopped offering sacrifices to the Queen of Heaven and pouring out liquid offerings to her, we have lacked everything, and we have been consumed by the sword and famine.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Indeed, we are going to continue offering sacrifices to the Queen of Heaven and pouring out liquid offerings to her. And do you think we have made cakes to represent her or poured out liquid offerings for her without our husbands’ approval?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Jeremiah spoke a message to all the people, to the young men, to the women, and to all the people who were answering him:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “As for the sacrifices that you, your ancestors, your kings, your officials, and the people of the land offered in the cities of Judah and the streets of Jerusalem, the Lord remembered them, did he not? And they came to his attention, did they not?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord could no longer bear it because of your evil deeds and the repulsive things that you did. So your land has become a ruin and an object of horror and ridicule without an inhabitant, as is the case today.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Because you offered sacrifices and sinned against the Lord, you didn’t obey the Lord and didn’t live according to his Law, his statutes, or his testimonies; therefore, this disaster has happened to you, as is the case today.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Jeremiah told all the people and all the women, “All you people of Judah who are in the land of Egypt, listen to this message from the Lord!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is what the Lord of the Heavenly Armies, the God of Israel, says: ‘You and your wives have spoken with your mouths and acted with your hands: “We will certainly carry through on the vows that we vowed to offer sacrifices to the Queen of Heaven and pour out liquid offerings to her!” Go ahead, carry through on your vows, and diligently do what you vowed!’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But listen to this message from the Lord, all you people of Judah who are living in the land of Egypt. ‘Look, I’ve sworn by my great name’, says the Lord, ‘my name will no longer be invoked by the mouth of any person in the entire land of Egypt, as he says, “As surely as the Lord God lives…”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “‘Look, I’m watching over them to bring disaster rather than good. Every person of Judah in the land of Egypt will be brought to an end by the sword and by famine until they’re completely gone.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The ones who escape the sword will return from the land of Egypt to the land of Judah, few in number. Then all the remnant of Judah who have come into the land of Egypt to settle will know whose message will stand, mine or theirs.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This will be a sign to you,’ declares the Lord, ‘that I’ll punish you in this place so that you may know that my words concerning disaster against you will surely stand.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is what the Lord says: “Look, I’m going to give Pharaoh Hophra, king of Egypt, into the hands of his enemies and into the hands of those seeking his life, just as I gave Zedekiah king of Judah into the hands of Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon, his enemy who was seeking his life.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is the message that Jeremiah the prophet spoke to Neriah’s son Baruch, when in the fourth year of the reign of Josiah’s son King Jehoiakim of Judah had, at Jeremiah’s dictation, written these words in a scroll:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “This is what the Lord God of Israel says to you, Baruch:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘You have said, “How terrible for me, for the Lord has added sorrow to my pain. I’m weary with my groaning, and I haven’t found rest.”’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Say this to him: ‘This is what the Lord says: “Look! What I’ve built I’m about to tear down, and what I’ve planted I’m about to pull up—and this will involve the entire land.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Are you seeking great things for yourself? Don’t seek them. Indeed, I’m about to bring disaster on all flesh,’ declares the Lord, ‘but your life will be spared wherever you go.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is the message from the Lord that came to Jeremiah the prophet concerning the nations.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: To Egypt: Concerning the army of King Pharaoh Neco of Egypt, which was encamped by the Euphrates River at Carchemish and which King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon defeated in the fourth year of the reign of Josiah’s son Jehoiakim, king of Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Prepare buckler and shield,
    and advance into the battle!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Harness the horses!
    Riders, mount up!
Take your positions with your helmets!
    Polish lances,
    and put on armor!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Why am I seeing this?
They’re terrified,
    they have turned back.
Their warriors are crushed,
    and they take flight.
They don’t look back.
    Terror is on every side,”
        declares the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“The swift cannot flee,
    nor can the strong escape.
In the north, beside the Euphrates River,
    they stumble and fall.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Who is this, rising like the Nile,
    like rivers whose waters surge?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Egypt is rising like the Nile,
    like rivers whose waters surge.
He says, ‘I’ll rise and cover the land.
    I’ll destroy the city and its inhabitants.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Horses, get up!
Chariots, drive furiously!
Let the warriors go forward,
    Ethiopia and Put, who carry shields,
        and the Lydians who handle and bend the bow.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
That day belongs to the Lord of the Heavenly Armies.
    It is a day of vengeance to take vengeance on his foes.
The sword will devour and be satisfied,
    and will drink its fill of their blood.
For the Lord God of the Heavenly Armies
    will hold a sacrifice in the land of the north,
        by the Euphrates river.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Go up to Gilead and get balm,
    virgin daughter of Egypt!
In vain you multiply remedies,
    but there is no healing for you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The nations have heard of your disgrace,
    and your cry of distress fills the earth.
Indeed, one warrior stumbles over another,
    and both of them fall down together.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is the message that the Lord spoke to Jeremiah the prophet about the coming of King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon to conquer the land of Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Announce in Egypt, proclaim in Migdol.
    Proclaim also in Memphis and Tahpanhes.
Say, ‘Take your positions and be ready,
    for the sword will devour all around you.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Why are your warriors prostrate?
    They don’t stand because the Lord has brought them down.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They repeatedly stumble and fall.
    They say to each other, ‘Get up!
Let’s go back to our people
    and to the land of our birth,
        away from the oppressor’s sword.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
There they’ll cry out,
‘Pharaoh, king of Egypt, is just a big noise.
    He has let the appointed time pass by.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
As certainly as I’m alive and living,” declares the King,
    whose name is the Lord of the Heavenly Armies,
“Indeed, one will come like Tabor among the mountains
    and like Carmel by the sea.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Prepare your baggage for exile,
    daughter living in Egypt,
for Memphis will become a desolate place.
    It will become a ruin without inhabitant.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Egypt is a beautiful calf,
    but a horsefly from the north is surely coming.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Even the mercenary troops in her ranks
    are like a fattened calf.
They too will turn around,
    and will flee together.
They won’t stand,
    for the day of their disaster is coming on them,
        the time of their punishment.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Her cry will be like that of a fleeing serpent
    when they come in strength.
        They’re coming to her with axes like woodcutters.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They’ll cut down her forest, though it’s impenetrable,”
    declares the Lord,
“for they’re more numerous than locusts,
    and there are too many of them to count.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The daughter of Egypt will be put to shame,
    she will be given into the hands of the people from the north.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord of the Heavenly Armies, the God of Israel says, “Look, I’m going to punish Amon of Thebes, Pharaoh, Egypt, its gods and its kings, Pharaoh, and those who trust in him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I’ll give them to those who are seeking their lives and to King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon and his officers. Then afterwards, Egypt will be inhabited as in times past,” declares the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“As for you, my servant Jacob, don’t be afraid,
    and Israel, don’t be dismayed.
For I’ll deliver you from a distant place,
    and your descendants from the land of their captivity.
Jacob will return.
    He will be undisturbed and secure,
        and no one will cause him to fear.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“As for you, my servant Jacob, don’t be afraid,
    and Israel, don’t be dismayed,”
        declares the Lord, “for I am with you.
Indeed, I’ll make an end of all the nations
    where I scattered you;
    but I won’t make an end of you!
I’ll discipline you justly,
    but I’ll certainly not leave you unpunished.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is the message from the Lord that came to Jeremiah the prophet concerning the Philistines, before Pharaoh conquered Gaza.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This is what the Lord says:
“Look, waters are rising from the north,
    and they’ll become an overflowing river.
They’ll overflow the land and all that fills it—
    the city and those that live in it.
People will cry out,
    and all those living in the land will wail.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
At the sound of the galloping hooves of his horses,
    at the rumbling of his chariots,
        the clatter of his wheels,
fathers won’t turn back for their children
    because their hands are weak,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
for the day is coming to destroy all the Philistines,
    to cut off from Tyre and Sidon
        every helper who remains.
For the Lord is destroying the Philistines,
    the remnant of the coastlands of Caphtor.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Baldness is coming to Gaza.
    Ashkelon is silenced.
Remnant of their valley,
    how long will you gash yourself?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Ah, sword of the Lord,
    how long before you are quiet?
Put yourself into your scabbard,
    be at rest, be silent!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
How can it be quiet,
    when the Lord has ordered disaster
to come to Ashkelon and the seashore?
    That’s where he has assigned it.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
To Moab: This is what the Lord of the Heavenly Armies, the God of Israel, says:
“How terrible for Nebo, for it’s laid waste.
    Kiriathaim is put to shame, it’s captured.
        The fortress is put to shame, it’s shattered.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The pride of Moab is no more.
    In Heshbon they plotted evil against her:
‘Come and let’s eliminate her as a nation.’
    Madmen will also be silenced,
        and the sword will pursue you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The sound of crying will come from Horonaim,
    devastation and great destruction.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Moab will be destroyed;
    her little ones will cry out.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Indeed, at the ascent of Luhith
    people will go up with bitter weeping.
At the descent of Horonaim
    the anguished cries over the destruction will be heard.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Flee, save your lives,
    and you will be like a wild donkey in the desert.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But, because you trust in your deeds and your riches,
    you will also be captured.
Chemosh will go out into exile,
    along with his priests and officials.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A destroyer will come to every town
    and no town will escape.
The valley will be ruined and the plateau destroyed.”
    This is what the Lord has said!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Put salt on Moab
    for she will surely fall.
Her towns will become desolate places,
    without any inhabitants in them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Cursed is the one who is slack
    in doing the Lord’s work.
Cursed is the one who holds back his sword
    from shedding blood.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Moab has been at ease from his youth.
    He has been undisturbed like wine on its dregs
        and not poured from vessel to vessel.
He has not gone into exile.
    Therefore, his flavor has remained,
        and his aroma has not changed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Therefore, look, days are coming,” declares the Lord, “when I’ll send those who tip over vessels to him, and they’ll tip him over. They’ll empty his vessels and shatter his jars.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moab will be ashamed because of Chemosh just as the house of Israel was ashamed because of Bethel, their confidence.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“How can you say, ‘We’re strong warriors,
    and soldiers ready for battle’?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Moab will be destroyed,
    and the enemy will come up against her cities.
Her finest young men will go down to slaughter,”
    declares the King,
        whose name is the Lord of the Heavenly Armies.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Moab’s disaster is near at hand,
    and his calamity is coming very quickly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Mourn for him, all who live around him,
    and all who know his name.
Say, ‘Oh how the mighty rod is broken,
    the glorious staff.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Come down from glory, and sit on parched ground,
    O woman who lives in Dibon,
for the destroyer of Moab will come up
    against you to destroy you.
        He will destroy your strongholds.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Stand by the road and keep watch,
    O woman who lives in Aroer.
Ask the man who flees and the woman who escapes.
    Say, ‘What happened’?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Moab will be put to shame,
    for it will be destroyed.
Wail and cry out.
    Announce by the Arnon that Moab is destroyed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Judgment has come to the plateau:
    to Holon and Jahzah,
and against Mephaath,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Dibon, Nebo, and Beth-diblathaim,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: against Kiriathaim, Beth-gamul, and Beth-meon,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
against Kerioth, Bozrah,
and all the towns in the land of Moab,
    both far and near.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The strength of Moab is cut off, and his arm is broken,”
    declares the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Make him drunk for he has exalted himself
    against the Lord.
Moab will wallow in his vomit,
    and he will be the object of mocking.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Wasn’t Israel an object of mocking for you?
    Wasn’t he treated like a thief,
so that whenever you spoke about him
    you shook your head in contempt?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Abandon the cities, and live on the cliffs,
    you inhabitants of Moab.
Be like a dove that builds a nest
    by the mouth of a cave.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
We have heard about Moab’s pride—
    he’s very proud—
his haughtiness, his arrogance,
    his insolence, and his conceit.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I know his gall,”
    declares the Lord,
“and it’s futile;
    the boasting that they do is futile.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Therefore, I’ll wail for Moab,
    and for the whole of Moab I’ll cry out,
    for the men of Kir-heres I’ll moan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
More than the weeping for Jazer,
    I’ll weep for you, vine of Sibmah.
Your branches spread out to the sea,
    and reached as far as the Sea of Jazer.
On your summer fruit and grapes
    the destroyer will fall.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Gladness and rejoicing will be taken away
    from the fruitful land.
From the land of Moab I’ll cause the wine
    in the wine presses to stop flowing.
The workers won’t tread the grapes with a loud shout.
    There will be no shout!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “From the cry of Heshbon, to Elealeh, to Jahaz they have lifted up their voice. From Zoar to Horonaim and to Eglath-shelishiyah, even the waters of Nimrim will become a desolate place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In Moab,” declares the Lord, “I’ll put an end to the one who offers a burnt offering on the high place and to the one who burns incense to his gods.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Therefore my heart wails for Moab like flutes and my heart wails for the men of Kir-heres like flutes. Therefore they’ll lose the abundance they produced.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Indeed every head will be bald and every beard cut short. There will be gashes on all the hands and sackcloth on the loins.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On all the housetops of Moab and in the streets there will be nothing but mourning, for I’ll break Moab like a vessel that no one wants,” declares the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “How it will be shattered! How they’ll wail! How Moab will turn his back in shame! Moab will be an object of ridicule and terror to all those around him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
For this is what the Lord says:
“Look, like an eagle one will fly swiftly
    and spread his wings against Moab.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The towns will be captured
    and the strongholds seized.
On that day the hearts of the warriors of Moab
    will be like the heart of a woman in labor.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Moab will be destroyed as a nation
    because he exalted himself against the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Terror, pit, and trap will be used against you
    who live in Moab,”
        declares the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“The one who flees from the terror
    will fall into a pit.
And the one who comes up out of the pit
    will be caught in a trap.
For I’ll bring upon her, that is upon Moab,
    the time of her punishment,”
        declares the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“The fugitives will stand without strength
    in the shadow of Heshbon,
for fire will go out from Heshbon
    and a flame from the middle of Sihon.
It will devour the forehead of Moab
    and the heads of the rebellious people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
How terrible for you, Moab!
    The people of Chemosh will perish.
Indeed, your sons will be taken into captivity,
    and your daughters as well.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But I’ll restore the fortunes of Moab in the latter days,”
    declares the Lord. 
This concludes the judgment on Moab.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
To the people of Ammon:
This is what the Lord says:
“Does Israel have no sons?
    Does he have no heir?
Why then has Milcom taken possession of Gad,
    and his people settled in its towns?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Therefore, look, the time is coming,”
    declares the Lord,
“when I’ll cause a battle cry to be heard in
    Rabbah of the Ammonites.
It will become a desolate mound,
    and its towns will be burned with fire.
Israel will take possession of those who possessed him,”
    says the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Wail, Heshbon, because Ai is destroyed.
    Cry out, daughters of Rabbah,
        put on sackcloth and lament.
Run back and forth inside the walls,
    for Milcom is going into exile
        along with his priests and his princes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Why do you boast in your valleys?
Your valley is flowing away, faithless daughter,
    who trusted in her treasures,
        saying, ‘Who will come against me?’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Look, I’m bringing terror on you from all around you,”
    declares the Lord God of the Heavenly Armies.
“You will be driven out, fleeing recklessly,
    and there will be no one to gather the fugitives.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But afterwards I’ll restore the fortunes of
    the people of Ammon,”
        declares the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
To Edom:
This is what the Lord of the Heavenly Armies says:
    “Is there no longer wisdom in Teman?
Has counsel perished among the prudent?
    Is their wisdom gone?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Flee, turn around!
    Go to a remote place to stay,
residents of Dedan!
    For I’ll bring Esau’s disaster on him
    at the time when I punish him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If the grape harvesters came to you,
    would they not leave gleanings?
If thieves came at night, they would destroy
    only until they had enough.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But I’ll strip Esau bare.
    I’ll uncover his hiding places so he cannot conceal himself.
His offspring, his relatives,
    and his neighbors will be destroyed,
        and he will no longer exist.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Leave your orphans. I’ll keep them alive.
    Let your widows trust in me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For this is what the Lord says: “Look, those who don’t deserve to drink the cup will surely drink it, and will you actually go unpunished? You won’t go unpunished! You will certainly drink it!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Indeed, I’ve sworn by myself,” declares the Lord, “that Bozrah will become an object of horror and scorn, a waste, and an object of ridicule. All her towns will become perpetual ruins.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I’ve heard a message from the Lord,
    and a messenger has been sent
        among the nations:
“Gather together and come up against her,
    and rise up to fight.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Indeed, I’ll make you the least of the nations,
    despised among men.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The terror you cause and the pride of your heart have deceived you.
You who live in hidden places in the rocks,
    who hold on to the heights of the hill,
although you make your nest high like the eagle,
    I’ll bring you down from there,”
        declares the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Edom will become an object of horror. Everyone who passes by her will be horrified and will scoff because of all her wounds.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Just like the overthrow of Sodom and Gomorrah and their neighbors,” says the Lord, “no one will live there. No human being will reside in it.
verses.speaker: Narrator
