verses.text: Look, like a lion comes up from the thicket of the Jordan to a pasture that grows year round, so I’ll drive them away from her in an instant, and I’ll appoint whomever is chosen over her. Indeed, who is like me? Who gives me counsel? Who is the shepherd who will stand against me?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Therefore, hear the plan that the Lord has made against Edom, and the strategy that he devised against the inhabitants of Teman. Surely he will drag the little ones of the flock away. Surely their pasture will be desolate because of them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The earth will quake at the sound of their fall. A cry—it’s her voice—is heard at the Reed Sea.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Look, he will rise up and fly swiftly like an eagle. He will spread his wings against Bozrah, and on that day the hearts of the warriors of Edom will be like the heart of a woman in labor.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
To Damascus:
“Hamath and Arpad will be humiliated.
    Their courage melts because they have heard bad news.
        There is anxiety like the sea that cannot be calmed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Damascus will become weak.
    She will turn to flee, but panic will seize her.
Distress and anguish will take hold of her
    like that of a woman giving birth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Why is the famous city, the joyful town,
    not abandoned?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Therefore her young men will fall in her streets,
    and all her soldiers will be silenced on that day,”
        declares the Lord of the Heavenly Armies.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“I’ll kindle a fire in the wall of Damascus,
    and it will devour the strongholds of Ben-hadad.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
To Kedar and the kingdoms of Hazor that King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon destroyed:
This is what the Lord says: 
“Arise, go against Kedar!
    Plunder the people of the east!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Take their tents and their flocks,
    their tent curtains and all their goods.
Take their camels away from them.
    Cry out against them, ‘Terror is all around!’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Flee! Run away quickly!
    Go to a remote place to stay, residents of Hazor,”
        declares the Lord.
“For King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon has formed a plan
    and devised a strategy against them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Arise, go up against a nation at ease, living securely,”
    declares the Lord,
        “without gates or bars, living alone.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Their camels will become booty,
    their many herds will become spoil.
I’ll scatter to the winds
    those who shave the corners of their beards,
and I’ll bring disaster on them from every side,”
    declares the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Hazor will become a dwelling place for jackals,
    a perpetual wasteland.
No one will live there;
    no human being will reside in it.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is what came as a message from the Lord to Jeremiah the prophet about Elam at the beginning of the reign of King Zedekiah of Judah:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This is what the Lord of the Heavenly Armies says:
“Look, I’m going to break the bow of Elam,
    the finest of their troops.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I’ll bring the four winds against Elam
    from the four corners of the heavens,
and I’ll scatter them to all these winds.
    There will be no nation to which the exiles
        from Elam won’t go.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I’ll terrify Elam before their enemies
    and before those who seek to kill them.
I’ll bring on them disaster and become fiercely angry at them,”
    declares the Lord.
“I’ll send the sword after them,
    until I’ve made an end of them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I’ll put my throne in Elam,
    and destroy the king and the officials there,”
        declares the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“But in the latter days I’ll restore
    the fortunes of Elam,”
        declares the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is the message that the Lord spoke through the prophet Jeremiah about Babylon, the land of the Chaldeans.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Declare and proclaim among the nations.
    Lift up a banner and proclaim.
Don’t conceal anything.
    Say, ‘Babylon will be captured.
Bel will be disgraced,
    and Marduk will be destroyed.
Her idols will be disgraced,
    and her filthy images will be destroyed.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
For a nation from the north will go up against her.
    It will make her land into an object of horror,
        and no one will live in it.
Both people and animals will wander off,
    and they’ll leave.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
In those days, and at that time,”
    declares the Lord,
“the people of Israel will come together
    with the people of Judah.
They’ll be weeping as they travel along,
    and they’ll be seeking the Lord their God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They’ll ask the way to Zion,
    turning their faces in that direction.
They’ll come and join themselves to the Lord
    in an everlasting covenant that won’t be forgotten.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
My people have become lost sheep.
    Their shepherds have led them astray,
        turning them toward the mountains.
They go from mountain to hill.
    They have forgotten their resting place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
All who find them devour them,
    but their enemies say, ‘We’re not guilty,
because they have sinned against
    the Lord, the habitation of righteousness,
        the Lord, the hope of their ancestors.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Move away from the middle of Babylon,
    and go out of the land of the Chaldeans.
        Be like male goats at the head of the flock.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Indeed, I’m going to stir up
    and bring against Babylon
a great company of nations
    from the land of the north.
They’ll deploy for battle against her,
    and from there she will be captured.
Their arrows will be like a skilled warrior;
    they won’t miss their targets.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The Chaldeans will become plunder,
    and all who plunder them will get more than enough,”
        declares the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Though you rejoice, though you exult,
    you plunderers of my inheritance,
though you skip around like a heifer in the grass
    and neigh like stallions,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
your mother will be greatly devastated,
    she who gave birth to you will be ashamed.
She will become the least of the nations,
    a wilderness, a dry land, and a desert.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Because of the anger of the Lord
    she won’t be inhabited,
    but will be utterly devastated.
Everyone who passes by Babylon will be horrified
    and will scoff because of all her wounds.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Deploy the troops all around Babylon.
    All who bend the bow, shoot at her
and spare no arrows,
    for she has sinned against the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Raise a battle cry against her on every side.
    She has surrendered, her pillars have fallen,
        her walls are thrown down.
For this is the vengeance of the Lord.
    Take vengeance on her;
        as she has done, do to her.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Eliminate from Babylon the one who plants seeds
    and the one who uses the sickle at harvest time.
Because of the oppressor’s sword, let each one turn
    toward his own people and flee to his own land.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Israel is a scattered flock, driven out by lions. The first to devour him was the king of Assyria, and then afterward King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon gnawed his bones.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Therefore this is what the Lord of the Heavenly Armies, the God of Israel, says: ‘Look, I’m about to judge the king of Babylon and his land, just as I’ve judged the king of Assyria.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I’ll bring Israel back to his pasture. He will graze on Carmel, on Bashan, on Mt. Ephraim, and on Gilead—his hunger will be satisfied.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In those days and at that time,’ declares the Lord, ‘the iniquity of Israel will be searched for, but there will be none; and the sin of Judah, but none will be found, because I’ll pardon those I leave as a remnant.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Go up against the land of Merathaim
    and the inhabitants of Pekod.
Kill them with swords, and completely destroy them,”
    declares the Lord,
        “and do everything that I’ve commanded you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The noise of battle is in the land,
    and great destruction.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
How the hammer of all the earth is cut off and broken!
    How Babylon has become a horror among the nations!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I’ll set a trap for you,
    and you will be caught, Babylon,
        but you don’t realize it.
You will be found and also seized,
    because you challenged the Lord!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“The Lord will open his armory,
    and bring out the weapons of his anger.
Indeed, a work of the Lord God of the Heavenly Armies
    will be in the land of the Chaldeans.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Come to her from afar.
    Open up her barns.
Pile her up like heaps of grain,
    and completely destroy her.
        Don’t leave any survivors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Put all her bulls to the sword,
    let them go down to the slaughter.
How terrible for them because their day has come,
    the time of their judgment.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“The sound of fugitives and refugees
    will come from the land of Babylon
to declare in Zion the vengeance of the Lord our God,
    vengeance for his Temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Summon many to Babylon,
    all those who bend the bow.
Camp all around her,
    let no one escape.
Repay her according to her deeds.
    Do to her just as she has done.
For she has behaved arrogantly against the Lord,
    against the Holy One of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Therefore, her warriors will fall in her streets,
    and all her soldiers will be silenced on that day,”
        declares the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Look, I’m against you, arrogant one,”
    declares the Lord God of the Heavenly Armies.
“Indeed your day is coming,
    the time of your judgment.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The arrogant one will stumble and fall,
    and there will be no one to lift him up.
I’ll set fire to his cities,
    and it will devour everything around him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This is what the Lord of the Heavenly Armies says:
“The people of Israel are oppressed,
    along with the people of Judah.
All their captors have held on to them
    and refused to let them go.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Their Redeemer is strong,
    the Lord of the Heavenly Armies is his name.
He will vigorously plead their case
    in order to bring rest to the earth,
        but turmoil to the inhabitants of Babylon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A sword against the Chaldeans,”
    declares the Lord,
“and against the inhabitants of Babylon,
    against her officials and her wise men.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A sword against the diviners.
    They’ll be made fools.
A sword against her warriors.
    They’ll be shattered.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A sword against her horses, against her chariots,
    and against all the foreign troops in her midst.
They’ll become women.
    A sword against her treasures.
    They’ll be plundered.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A drought against her waters.
    They’ll dry up.
For it’s a land of idols,
    and they go mad over their terrifying images.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Therefore the desert creatures
    along with hyenas will live there.
They’ll live in it with ostriches,
    but people won’t live in it again.
        They won’t inhabit it from generation to generation.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Just as when God overthrew Sodom,
    Gomorrah, and their neighbors,”
        declares the Lord,
“so also no one will live there.
    No human being will reside in it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Look, people are coming from the north.
    A great nation and many kings will be stirred up
        from the ends of the earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They grab bow and spear.
    They’re cruel and show no mercy.
Their sound roars like the sea,
    as they ride on horses
deployed like men ready for battle
    against you, daughter of Babylon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The king of Babylon has heard the news about them,
    and his hands hang limp.
Distress has seized him,
    like a woman in labor.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Look, like a lion comes up from the thicket of the Jordan to a pasture that grows year round, so I’ll drive them away from her in an instant, and I’ll appoint whomever is chosen over her. Indeed, who is like me? Who gives me counsel? Who is the shepherd who will stand against me?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Therefore, hear the plan that the Lord has made against Babylon, and the strategy that he devised against the land of the Chaldeans. Surely they’ll drag the little ones of the flock away. Surely their pasture will be desolate because of them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At the shout that Babylon has been seized, the earth will be shaken, and the cry will be heard among the nations.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This is what the Lord says:
“Look, I’m going to stir up a destroying wind
    against Babylon and the inhabitants of Leb-kamai.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I’ll send foreigners to Babylon,
    and they’ll winnow her,
        and devastate her land.
They’ll come against her from every side
    on the day of her disaster.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Don’t let the archer bend the bow;
    don’t let him rise up in his armor.
Don’t spare her young men.
    Completely destroy her entire army.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The slain will fall in the land of Chaldea,
    pierced through in her streets.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Indeed, Israel and Judah haven’t been
    abandoned by their God,
by the Lord of the Heavenly Armies,
    although their land is full of guilt
        against the Holy One of Israel.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Flee from Babylon,
    and each of you, escape with your life!
Don’t be destroyed because of her guilt,
    for it’s time for the Lord’s vengeance.
        He is paying back what is due to her.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Babylon was a golden cup in the Lord’s hand,
    making the whole earth drunk.
The nations drank her wine,
    therefore the nations have gone mad.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Suddenly, Babylon fell down and was shattered.
    Wail for her!
Bring balm for her wound,
    perhaps she will be healed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
We tried to heal Babylon,
    but she wouldn’t be healed.
Leave her, and let each of us go to his own country.
    For her judgment has reached to the heavens,
        and is lifted up to the sky.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The Lord will vindicate us.
    Come! Let us declare the work of the Lord our God in Zion.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Sharpen the arrows, fill the quivers!
The Lord has stirred up the spirit
    of the kings of the Medes—
        he has decided to destroy Babylon.
Indeed, it’s the Lord’s vengeance,
    vengeance for his Temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Lift up the battle standard against Babylon’s walls.
    Strengthen the guard;
        post watchmen.
Set men in position for an ambush.
    For the Lord will both plan and carry out what he has
        declared against the inhabitants of Babylon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You who live beside many waters,
    rich in treasures,
your end has come,
    your life thread is cut.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The Lord of the Heavenly Armies
    has sworn by himself:
“I’ll surely fill you with soldiers like a swarm of locusts,
    and they’ll sing songs of victory over you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He made the earth by his power.
    He established the world by his wisdom,
        and by his understanding he spread out the heavens.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When his voice sounds, there is thunder from
    the waters of heaven,
and he makes clouds rise up
    from the ends of the earth.
He makes lightning for the rain
    and brings wind out of his storehouses.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Everyone is stupid and without knowledge.
    Every goldsmith is put to shame by his own idols,
for his images are false,
    and there is no life in them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They’re worthless, a work of mockery,
    and when the time of punishment comes,
        they’ll perish.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The Portion of Jacob is not like these.
    He made everything,
including the tribe of his inheritance.
    The Lord of the Heavenly Armies is his name.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“You are my war-club and
    weapons of war.
I’ll smash nations with you
    and destroy kingdoms with you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I’ll smash the horse and its rider with you.
    I’ll smash the chariot and its rider with you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I’ll smash man and woman with you.
    I’ll smash old man and young boy with you.
        I’ll smash young man and young woman with you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I’ll smash the shepherd and his flock with you.
    I’ll smash the farmer and his team of oxen with you.
        I’ll smash governors and officials with you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Before your eyes I’ll repay Babylon and all the inhabitants of Chaldea for all the evil that they did in Zion,” declares the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Look, I’m against you, destroying mountain,
    who destroys the whole earth,”
        declares the Lord.
“I’ll stretch out my hand against you
    and roll you down from the crags.
        And I’ll make you a burned-out mountain.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They won’t get a cornerstone
    or a foundation stone from you,
because you will be a wasteland forever,”
    declares the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Lift up a battle standard in the land.
    Blow a trumpet among the nations.
Consecrate the nations against her.
    Summon the kingdoms of Ararat, Minni,
        and Ashkenaz against her.
Appoint a commander against her,
    bring up horses like bristling locusts.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Consecrate the nations against her,
    the kings of the Medes, their governors, their prefects,
        and every land under their domination.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The land quakes and writhes
    because the Lord’s purposes
against Babylon stand firm,
    to make the land of Babylon a waste without inhabitants.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
One runner runs to meet another runner,
    and one messenger to meet another messenger,
to tell the king of Babylon that his city has been seized
    from one end to the other.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The fords have been captured,
    and the marshes burned with fire.
        The soldiers are terrified.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
For this is what the Lord of the Heavenly Armies,
    the God of Israel, says:
“The daughter of Babylon is like a threshing floor
    at the time when it’s pounded down.
In just a little while, the time of her harvest will come.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon has devoured me
    and crushed me.
He set me down
    like an empty vessel.
He swallowed me like a monster,
    and filled his belly with my delicacies.
        Then he washed me away.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
May the violence done to me
    and my flesh be on Babylon,”
        says the inhabitant of Zion.
“May my blood be on the inhabitants of Chaldea,”
    says Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Therefore this is what the Lord says: 
“Look, I’m going to argue your case
    and take vengeance for you.
I’ll dry up her sea
    and make her fountain dry.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Babylon will become a heap of ruins,
    a refuge for jackals,
a desolate place
    and an object of scorn.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They’ll roar together like young lions;
    they’ll growl like lion cubs.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When they’re excited I’ll serve them their banquet,
    and make them drunk until they’re merry.
They’ll sleep forever and won’t wake up,”
    declares the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“I’ll bring them down like lambs for the slaughter,
    like rams with male goats.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“How Sheshak will be captured,
    and the prince of all the earth seized!
How Babylon will become an object of horror
    among the nations!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The sea will come up against Babylon,
    and she will be covered by wave upon wave.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Her cities will become an object of horror,
    a dry land and a desert,
a land in which no one lives,
    and through which no human being passes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I’ll punish Bel in Babylon,
    and I’ll make what he has swallowed
        come out of his mouth.
The nations will no longer stream to him.
    Even the wall of Babylon will fall.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Come out of her, my people,
    flee for your lives from the Lord’s anger!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do this now, so your heart does not grow faint,
    and so you don’t become frightened
        because of the rumors that are heard in the land—
a rumor comes one year and then after it
    another rumor comes the next year
about violence in the land
    and one ruler against another ruler.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Therefore, look, days are coming
    when I’ll punish the idols of Babylon.
Her entire land will be put to shame,
    and all her slain will fall in her midst.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then the heavens and the earth
    and all that are in them
        will shout for joy about Babylon
because the destroyers will come
    out of the north against her,”
        declares the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“So Babylon will fall
    because of the slain of Israel,
even as the slain of all the earth
    have fallen because of Babylon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Go, you who escaped the sword!
    Don’t stand around!
Remember the Lord from far away,
    and let Jerusalem come to your mind.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
We have been put to shame
    because we have heard insults.
Disgrace has covered our faces because foreigners have
    come into the Holy Places of the Lord’s house.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Therefore, look, days are coming,”
    declares the Lord,
“when I’ll punish her idols,
    and throughout her land the wounded will groan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Though Babylon should reach up to the heavens
    and fortify her high fortresses,
from me destroyers will come to her,”
    declares the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“The sound of a cry is coming from Babylon,
    great destruction from the land of the Chaldeans.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
For the Lord is destroying Babylon,
    and he will make the loud sounds from her disappear.
Their waves will roar like many waters,
    the noise of their voices will sound forth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Indeed, the destroyer is coming against her,
    against Babylon.
Her warriors are captured,
    and her bows are broken.
For the Lord is a God of recompense,
    and he will repay in full.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I’ll make their leaders, their wise men,
    their governors, their deputies,
and their warriors drunk so that they sleep forever
    and don’t wake up,”
declares the King
    whose name is the Lord of the Heavenly Armies.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This is what the Lord of the Heavenly Armies says: 
“The broad wall of Babylon will be completely leveled,
    and its high gate set on fire.
and so the peoples toil for nothing,
    and the nations weary themselves only for fire.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is the message that Jeremiah the prophet delivered to Neriah’s son Seraiah, the grandson of Mahseiah, when he went with King Zedekiah of Judah to Babylon in the fourth year of his reign. Seraiah was the quartermaster.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jeremiah wrote on a single scroll all the disasters that would come on Babylon, all these things that were written about Babylon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jeremiah told Seraiah, “When you come to Babylon, see that you read all these words,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and say, ‘Lord, you have declared about this place that you would destroy it so that there wouldn’t be an inhabitant in it, neither human nor animal, because it will be a wasteland forever.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When you finish reading this scroll, tie a rock around it and throw it into the middle of the Euphrates.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then say, ‘Babylon will sink like this and won’t rise from the disaster that I’m bringing on her. Her people will be exhausted.’”
This concludes the writings of Jeremiah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Zedekiah was 21 years old when he began to rule, and he ruled for 11 years in Jerusalem. His mother’s name was Hamutal, the daughter of Jeremiah of Libnah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Zedekiah had done evil in the Lord’s sight, just as Jehoiakim had done.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Because Jerusalem and Judah had angered the Lord, he cast them out of his presence. Zedekiah rebelled against the king of Babylon,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and in the ninth year of his reign, in the tenth month, on the tenth day, King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon came against Jerusalem with all his army. He encamped near it and set up siege works all around it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The city was under siege until the eleventh year of the reign of King Zedekiah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: By the ninth day of the fourth month the famine became so severe that there was no food for the people of the land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The wall of the city was broken through, and all the soldiers fled, leaving the city at night through the gate between the two walls next to the king’s garden, even though the Chaldeans were all around the city. They went in the direction of the Arabah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Chaldean army went after the king, overtook Zedekiah in the plains of Jericho, and all his troops were scattered from him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They captured the king and brought him to the king of Babylon at Riblah in the land of Hamath, where the king of Babylon passed judgment on him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king of Babylon killed Zedekiah’s sons before his eyes, and he also killed all the Judean officials at Riblah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He blinded Zedekiah and bound him in bronze shackles. Then the king of Babylon took him to Babylon and put him in prison until he died.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the fifth month, on the tenth day of the month—it was the nineteenth year of the reign of King Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylon—Nebuzaradan the captain of the guard who served the king of Babylon, entered Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He burned the Lord’s Temple, the king’s house, and all the houses in Jerusalem. He also burned every public building with fire.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the Chaldean troops who were with the captain of the guard tore down all the walls around Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Nebuzaradan the captain of the guard carried into exile some of the poorest of the people, the rest of the people left in the city, the deserters who had defected to the king of Babylon, and the rest of the craftsmen.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Nebuzaradan the captain of the guard left some of the poorest people of the land to be vinedressers and farmers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Chaldeans broke in pieces the bronze pillars that were in the Lord’s Temple and the stands and the bronze sea that were in the Lord’s Temple, and they carried all the bronze to Babylon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They took away the pots, the shovels, the snuffers, the basins, the pans, and all the bronze utensils that were used in the temple service.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The captain of the guard took away the bowls, the fire pans, the basins, the pots, the lamp stands, the pans, and the bowls for libations, both those made of gold and those made of silver.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There was too much bronze to weigh in the two pillars, the one sea, the twelve bronze oxen that were under the sea, and the stands which King Solomon had made for the Lord’s Temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Each of the pillars was twelve cubits high and its circumference twelve cubits. It was hollow and about a handbreadth thick.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On each pillar was a capital of bronze, and the height of each capital was five cubits. Latticework and pomegranates, all of bronze, were all around the capital. And the second pillar was like this, including the pomegranates.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There were 96 pomegranates open to view. In all, there were 100 pomegranates all around the latticework.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The captain of the guard arrested Seraiah the chief priest, Zephaniah the next ranking priest, and the three guards of the gate.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: From the city he arrested one of the officers who had been in charge of the troops, seven men from the king’s personal advisors who were found in the city, the secretary of the commander of the army who mustered the people of the land, and 60 men of the people of the land who were found inside the city.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Nebuzaradan the captain of the guard arrested them and brought them to the king of Babylon at Riblah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king of Babylon struck them down and killed them at Riblah in the land of Hamath. So Judah went into exile from the land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These are the people Nebuchadnezzar took into exile: in the seventh year, 3,023 Judeans;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: in Nebuchadnezzar’s eighteenth year, 832 people from Jerusalem;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: in Nebuchadnezzar’s twenty-third year, Nebuzaradan the captain of the guard took 745 people from Judah into exile. All the people taken into exile numbered 4,600.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the first year of his reign, King Evil-merodach of Babylon, showed favor to King Jehoiachin of Judah by releasing him from prison on the twenty-fifth day of the twelfth month in the thirty-seventh year of the exile of King Jehoiachin of Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He spoke kindly to him and gave him a seat above the seats of the other kings who were in Babylon with him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jehoiachin changed his prison clothes and regularly dined with the king as long as he lived.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As for his living expenses, a regular allowance was given him daily by the king of Babylon as long as he lived, until the day of his death.
verses.speaker: Narrator
